column10:
*please note I have more hours on console*

How is the game?: 
-If you are a DBZ fan or hell a fan of any Dragon Ball in the slightest pick this up. While this does have Bamco's annoying DLC practices attached it is a super well made 2D fighter. Arc Sys really nailed down their 2D aesthetic. 
-The game is super fun and offers a casual experience on the surface making it a nice casual game for winding down. On the flipside if you dig into the nuts and bolts you will be rewarded with an excellent fighter that can be played competitively. 
-The game offers combo trials for each character allowing you to get a taste of what each character can do before worrying about assists. This is a 3v3 fighter meaning you can do some really cool assists and tags which adds another layer of sauce to the mix. 
-The game does not require a supercomputer to play so if you could totally run this on a lower spec gaming laptop and bring it to a friends house. 
-Story mode is not super great. It is not really done very well and the writing feels super stilted and you will probably want to skip cutscenes which is generous as it really is character models standing and talking. But if you are bored and want to learn some of the games basics it is there to chew on. Just don't expect a Martin Scorsese cinematic classic. Is it worse than SFV's? Very debatable.

The Netcode and online:
-Well there was a rollback beta for the PC version (which you are likely thinking about picking up if you are reading this on Steam) but it has since vanished so we return to really annoying delay based netcode. Which is great if you can find ranked matches with reliable connections but don't hold your breath. You won't. Rollback is coming and it is a thing but it just is not here and I hope the player count can come back up a bit when it is implemented. It really is annoying that some of these excellent fighters have to be held back due to poor netcode and delay based implementation. 

DLC and Stuff: 
-Yeah the DLC is kind of overpriced. I would recommend getting one of the more expensive editions if it is on sale but with packs vs individual characters I would do the math and do what is best for your wallet. That is all I really have to say on that lol.

TLDR: 
-Game good, buy on sale if you can, price out the DLC with what you want or if you want it all it is there. Story is mid to terrible but there instead of not there. Mechanically fun but the netcode is pretty ass so get used to the occasional 8-10 frame delay. If you are lucky you will only have to deal with 2 frames of delay. In my opinion it is worth a buy even off sale but due to the negatives I am not sure I would recommend that. If you are a fan of the franchise you will find a super well made fighter to enjoy.

Does anyone else think Shenron is actually really hot? Shenron is the reason I work out. I have this fantasy where we start talking at the Vanity Fair Oscars party bar. We exchange a few pleasantries. He asks what I do. I say I loved him in Dragon Ball. He laughs. I get my drink. "Well, see ya," I say and walk away. I've got his attention now. How many guys voluntarily leave a conversation with Shenron? He touches his scales as he watches me leave. Later, as the night's dragged on and the coterie of gorgeous narcissists grows increasingly loose, he finds me on the balcony, my bowtie undone, smoking a cigarette. "Got a spare?" he asks. "What's in it for me?" I say as I hand him one of my little white ladies. He smiles. "Conversation with me, duh." I laugh. "What's so funny?" He protests. "Nothing, nothing... It's just... don't you grow tired of the egos?" "You get used to it," He says, lighting his cigarette and handing me back the lighter. "What would you do if you weren't a divinely powerful dragon god?" I ask. "Teaching, I think." "And if I was your student, what would I be learning?" "Discipline," He says quickly, looking up into my eyes, before changing the subject. "Where are you from?" "Bermuda," I say. "Oh wow. That's lovely." "It's ok," I admit. "Not everything is to my liking." "What could possibly be not to your liking in Bermuda?" He inquires. "I don't like sand," I tell him. "It's coarse and rough and irritating and it gets everywhere."

Great game, but there are definitely better fighting games on the market. It's really easy to pick up, but if you're looking for a competitive game, I would suggest different games. This game is too combo based with barely any neutral or time between combos. You'll spend more time in training room than online because you'll get obliterated if you don't know 200 hit combos. If you like really combo based games, then you might like this game, but there are better combo based games that are also more balanced out there (UMVC3, GGST, etc.). Definitely a fun game, don't get me wrong, but not a "must buy".

Jogo de luta feito pela Arc System é alta qualidade na certa e com FighterZ não podia ser diferente. Esse é o único jogo de dragon ball que realmente é um fighter competitivo com diversas mecânicas ofensivas e defensivas, bom balanceamento, um roster extremamente variado que com certeza possuirá personagens para seu estilo de jogo e vai ter rollback futuramente (melhor forma de conexão para jogos de luta onde você geralmente joga sem lag/ sem problema algum de input delay).

Dragon Ball Fighterz é um anime fighter/versus game 3x3 com movimentação frenética, golpes com grandes hitbox e combos gigantescos, se você já jogou games como marvel vs capcom ou skullgirls você tem uma ideia inicial de onde está se metendo, apesar desse jogo possuir diversas diferenças e novas mecânicas que tornam ele um game bem diferente e único se comparado aos citados.

Para os fãs de jogos de luta competitivo, esse jogo é um prato cheio com personagens dos mais diversos arquétipos (apesar de todos também meio que serem rushdown pela ideia de alta velocidade do game), alta complexidade envolvendo muita estratégia e decisões, alto nível de execução de combos, pensamento na estrutura dos times, mixups insanos e grande espaço para "player expression", recompensando os melhores jogadores ao contrário de jogos de luta mais casuais. Futuramente ele receberá rollback netcode que muito provavelmente vai atrair ainda mais player para o online e "revivê-lo" . Por ser um jogo da Arc você encontrará um vasto conteúdo online para aprender o jogo como páginas no dustloops, guias no youtube e servers no discord.

Para os fãs de dragon ball, é incrível o sentimento de batalha igualzinho ao anime que esse jogo passa, com movimentos extremamente rápidos, lutas no ar, explosões para todo lado, mudança de cenário durante a luta (incluindo uma explosão que pode ser tão forte que destrói o cenário inteiro), golpes exageradíssimos e poderosos, contendo todos os principais personagens mais amados da franquia, com eles sendo retratados com perfeição em sua gameplay, além do jogo possuir um estilo gráfico e de animação incrível que só a arc consegue executar, replicando muito bem o visual do anime, não sendo como outros jogos de dragon ball que os personagens são claramente um modelo 3D totalmente diferente dos animes.

Para os fãs mais casuais de jogos de luta, não se assuste com o fato desse game ser um jogo de luta competitivo, pois ele possui diversas mecânicas que te auxiliam a aprender o básico do jogo e se divertir mesmo sendo ruim nesse gênero de fighter como auto-combo e um padrão nos motion input de especiais e supers, sendo a grande maioria (ou até mesmo todos? não lembro) um comando de 236 (famoso meia lua) ou 214 (famoso meia lua pra trás) + algum botão. Contra quem realmente sabe jogar o game em nível competitivo essas mecânicas novas não vão te carregar e você será completamente amassado, mas para jogar de forma casual com amigos eles são mais do que o suficiente para lhe proporcionar muita diversão e um sentimento de "sou f*da, me sinto um pro player, olha esses combos que consigo fazer no game" enquanto você só está spammando um monte de botão e terminando a sequencia em alguns supers.


Recomendo demais esse jogo tanto para o publico competitivo quanto o público causal de jogos de luta, é um dos melhores jogos de luta modernos e o melhor dragon ball até o momento. De preferência pegue a Ultimate Edition para ter todos os personagens.

Vou deixar aqui um vídeo que fala sobre a animação espetacular desse game e algumas técnicas que a Arc utiliza pra recriar esse visual e sentimento de anime 2D mesmo sendo um jogo 3D: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kZsboyfs-L4

If you're going to buy this game, just save your money and don't. The amount of input errors is *absolutely unplayable* if the frame delay changes by even one. I have never, ever seen any game of any genre with netcode this bad. Beyond that, the connection details are misleading, and queueing for blue connection might as well have you waiting a year.
EDIT: Honestly, I don't think rollback is gonna fix this issue, as well. Even if the frame delay doesn't change whatsoever, the game itself chugs so bad because of EAC, even with the supposed "fix", that your inputs drop regardless. I can verify this from the beta.

This is one of my favorite games but I will try not to be biased.

Positives:
-The game looks stunning especially during the dramatic finishes and for the super moves.

-The roster is pretty big and I believe that they did a good job with their selections (I would've liked kid Gohan or Raditz)

-This is a good example of an easy to pick up but difficult to master game, especially in my first few months of playing I saw great improvements in my skill from both watching others play and simply messing around

-Incredibly fun if you have friends to play with who are also good at the game (but I guess that can be said about any multiplayer game)

Cons:
-Auto-Combos make the game feel too accessible, its very easy to just spam light attacks and pray you win

-The story mode is pretty boring, by the final arc (which is even more boring than the previous 2) I had already turned my brain off and just auto-piloted myself through. This is even more annoying when it is necessary to do story mode if you want to play as android 21

-Besides online and monthly boss events there isn't much to do after beating all classic mode maps and beating story mode

-A lot of the DLC characters are pay-2-win mostly the fusions, Z Broly and lab coat 21, this makes online unbearable when almost all teams have atleast 1 of them.
i think goku might be in this game

[h1]For All The DBZ Fans![/h1]
After the success of the Xenoverse series, it’s time to introduce a new classic 2D DRAGON BALL fighting game for this generation’s consoles. DRAGON BALL FighterZ is born from what makes the DRAGON BALL series so loved and famous: endless spectacular fights with its all powerful fighters. Partnering with Arc System Works, DRAGON BALL FighterZ maximizes high end Anime graphics and brings easy to learn but difficult to master fighting gameplay to audiences worldwide.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]I absolutely love the artstyle! It’s so sharp and the cell shading is next level. The special effects are intense and the ultimate ability cutscenes look so similar to the DBZ and DBS show. Amazing attention to detail overall! Animations are just insane as well. The developers really took notes from the shows, and they did just a perfect job with it. Definitely the best looking DBZ game out there (in my opinion).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]Gameplay is just so top tier! The game is pretty similar to many 2D fighting games and that’s not a bad thing at all. The foundation of what makes a 2D fighting game is here, with many improvements. The character entrances are all unique from each other and are a picture perfect replication of the source material. Even many of the attacks and special moves look really similar to the source material. If you watched DBZ/DBS you will immediately catch on to this and will have the biggest smile on your face. The developers are definitely fans of the series! The combat is pretty simple and easy to learn. You have your simple, medium, and heavy attack moves and your special abilities that are unique from each character (but some button layouts are similar to other characters). You also have other abilities as well that keeps the combat intense (ki blast, teleporting, and other attack moves). The game is pretty easy to learn, but hard to master since many characters feel different from each other. Practice mode will be really important if you want to be pretty good at this game. You have a zapping system since you can pick up to three characters per match to change from. This adds an extra layer of flow, and mechanics that requires some skill to get good at. One big complaint is that the AI can be pretty inconsistent. You need to find the perfect balance of difficulty because they either are just plain dumb, or actual gods here! If you are looking for a somewhat casual fighting experience, this may not be for you. Just keep that in mind if you are not willing to take the time to practice and get good at this game. Also another complaint is that the content in the base game is pretty lacking. This game is missing many well known characters if you are just buying the base game. This is frustrating because I know many DBZ games back then had tons of characters to use. Also the stages are pretty lacking. No DBS stages, but has DBS characters if you get the fighter packs. This feels like a big oversight from the devs.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]The story is pretty forgettable and boring in my opinion. I didn’t care about the villain and the overall story arc. It felt super linear with no interesting twist or character building. I did like some of the dialogue between characters, but besides that I didn’t feel interested and invested in the story. Not much to say here, just not worth replaying at all and doesn’t feel that rewarding.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎭Multiplayer[/td]
        [td]The multiplayer is pretty straightforward and overall really fun. Being able to meet new people at the game hub is pretty cool as well. You have some unlockables (in terms of lobby characters and profile decorations). I haven’t had any serious connections issues as well.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]With friends and overall just fighting AI, you can add a good amount of playtime here. There’s no deep progression or anything deep in that regard. It’s a straightforward experience, but a fun experience nonetheless. The story is around 12+ hours long. And getting all achievements may take you around 40+ hours of playtime.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]Sound is superb! The music is pretty solid and the voice actors did a great job. The combat also sounds really intense and addicting! The overall sound design is really good with no complaints at all![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]I haven’t really encountered any bugs from my experience. The game felt really optimized in terms of bugs.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]Performance was really good on my end. No lag, crashes or even stutters. You should be perfectly fine if you have similar or even a little lower end specs in my opinion.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Fantastic graphics
[*]Cool in-game lobby
[*]Many great references
[*]Great combat and flow
[*]tournament and arcade mode
[*]Artstyle similar to DBZ/DBS
[*]Awesome fighting mechanics
[*]Easy to learn/Hard to master
[*]Respect to the source material
[*]Animations/attack moves are similar to the DBZ and DBS show
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Many characters locked behind paywall
[*]Not many stages (not even a DLC for stages)
[*]Story Mode is forgettable and not interesting
[*]AI can be pretty inconsistent (either they don't do much at all, or are absolute gods)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]8/10
Buy the Ultimate edition on sale for 75% off (and get the fighter packs as well). Overall should be around $40 with all the content and DLC’s.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]If you are a fan of the Dragon Ball franchise, then this is a must buy! I do recommend saving some extra money to get all of the DLC’s since this game is lacking content in the base game. The combat is absolutely fast paced, intense and so addicting. The developers showed so much love to the source material as well. This is the perfect fighting game for all of the Dragon Ball fans and just fighting fans in general![/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

Where Dragonball FighterZ excels: its 'easy to use' for the layman fighting system, with more advanced combos for those taking it more seriously and well accustomed to fighting games. And the visuals and voice overs ooze DBZ vibes. 

Where FighterZ could easily be so much more: there could have been a LOT more characters easily, and when you compare the roster to previous titles like Budokai Tenkaichi 3 that had around 200 characters nearly, you can see that. Mods are working online again atm though, (edit: only if they have same mods as you I think maybe, even then I'm not 100% sure you won't desync using mods online, when I tried with my friend who was without mods, we desynced, I had to launch vanilla so we wouldn't desync, but at least you can have one .exe for modded and launch regular from steam for vanilla..)  so that's nice and offers some way you can customize, you can find some nice ones to recreate the battles that you want to, like Majin Vegeta or Mecha Freiza, first & 2nd form Cell, etc.. You would think steam workshop would be an easy no brainer here..

It's also worth noting of course that this is a much more classic fighting game, so there's that, and it works, and it is compounding many different tried gameplay tactics over the years from Bandai, so while it is a 'simple fighting game', it has all of that to draw from as to what works and what doesn't. You may not be freely sprawling across a huge but poorly rendered space (ala Dragonball Legends), or taking 3d flight like Tenkaichi 3; but alot of that sort of chaff is cut and in its place is a close up, intense, ki blasting, adrenaline filled fight from start to finish.

    So does the game do a fantastic job of carrying forward the awesome legacy of the vanish fights from Budokai 3? Is the game better than Budokai 3? Well, yes and no, to both of these.
But also, again, this game is more of a straightforward classic fighting game, so is it even a fair comparison.
 The dragon rush system is certainly much more optimal here for multiplayer, in the days of Budokai 3 however the dragon rush was innovative and maybe at the time the best way they could do it, but when it comes to more serious tournaments dragon rush's would often be banned because of how trivial of a gimmick it is seen to be, guessing or randomly hitting the same button as the rusher. So, the way dragon rush works here is a big improvement, and in that respect it was a step in the right direction as far as that movement goes. There are actually two types of rush here and they both work better than most other DBZ title's rush mechanic. Of the many DBZ titles I have played, this is one of the best ways to do the flying towards your opponent aspect. In general out of all DBZ titles, this game has some of the best fights and really feels like the show. 

Another thing is for instance while most characters have at least one or two specific combos like they did in Budokai 3, the basic combo inputs are the same across pretty much all the characters, for better or for worse, it does make it fun and casual friendly to change up characters and still know the combos but it's also more basic that way and a bit less specific to each character, making it (unless you learn every combo) a bit the same after a while. whereas if there were more combos that were character specific but not as long and complicated and drawn out as some of them which are hard to pull of, and easier to remember that would be cool but, anyway.

Characters attacks often are on point as far as being like they were in the show,
Artwork and animations in this game are very aesthetic
For best epic results mute music, and play with a playlist of DB music of your own, we use watch2gether so our music is sync'd up with eachother, and have many of the Bruce Faulconer score tracks on our playlist so it is epic!
Fun with friends, fights look and feel like the show for the most part.
There are some nice attention to detail like for instance ki blasts that get diverted into exploding in the background, by your character powering up or deflecting them, the destruction and dramatic finishes, voiceover Chistopher Sabat & Sean Schemmel, etc.., watching back your fights with character commentating over them ( this reminded me of Dragonball Legends character changeout screen : )  )
Don't expect much from the 'story' though, lol, but, c'mon, it's a straight fighting game lol. 

Another missed opportunity is the arena matches, who knows the exact reason most players simply ignore the arena match option, probably because people can watch I think? It wasn't until recently that I noticed it had different types of fights you can do which is cool and adds replay value, for instance with 'flashy fight' you can always vanish, which really brings back the Budokai 3 Vanish fights vibe, like when you equipped meditation lol. That's another thing that Budokai 3 had more of of course, more customization and probably the best story mode of any DBZ game so far ( have not played kakarot). Recently I have noticed people using arena match more, so some have finally taken notice of it.

Really a pretty fantastic DBZ fighting game. It plays a lot like Marvel Vs Capcom 3, if I had to compare it to something; Sparking! acts in much the same way as X factor. And the tag team change between characters, and specials with quarter circles, all that. But it is more layman friendly than MVC3. 
 
The game we needed after Budokai series...? Doing it justice...? Maybe. Probably. It is a more traditional fighting game compared to the Budokai's, and it worked well. The dragon rush system here as I said being much better suited for multiplayer than Budokai 3's (known to be its one snag). If you were into Budokai, well I was too, and IMO this is pretty good. 

Namek is probably the most gorgeous stage, although a few more wouldn't hurt -- A desert stage with Buu's house &/or Babidi's lair entrance in the background would be cool! Also Kami's lookout seems like a no brainer, rather than ugly boring galactic arena stage. (Someone make this mod)
However my suggestions aside of course who wouldn't be pleased with the excellent fighting system that is there : )
The dramatic finishes are awesome, but it would be better if they weren't limited to only a single stage. 

I look forward to maybe some of these suggestions being taken into consideration and showing up in FighterZ 2!!???!

One thing I will say is after about 70-80 hours, you can play any character because the basic attacks are the same; but you will reach a skill ceiling where you can not lose a character to newbs, & go head to head with some orange & pinks, but then you will get the pinks that just do not let you move at all. When the combo lasts so long that you are sitting there for 30 seconds pressing buttons and can't move at all, there is no point, lol. 
I suppose its akin to when our grandparents would break in billiards and get a ball in, and so then would run the table, but, this is a little extreme, lol.

This is one of those "easy to learn, hard to master" type of fighting games, which I think is a good thing. This is also a more competitive fighting game, where you're going to struggle a bit before you get better and start winning more. Practicing combos and the assist system in this game are essential things if you want to move up the ranks. The game does have multiple dlc characters, but they are relatively cheap and not at all necessary if you want to win. Of course, some dlc characters are better than other characters, but playing as the better character will only get you but so far. This is a "skill to win" game that you will need to develop skill for. If you're into fighting games like this, then Fighterz is a perfect option for you.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

This game genuinely surprised me with how much quality and love went into it! If you have played any licensed video game, specifically licensed Anime games, you'll know they are usually poor quality cash grabs (technically I'd say this game does overprice itself and it's DLC. Look for sales, I got the FighterZ edition for like $14usd), but FigherZ being developed by Arc, who are known for quality Fighting Games, shows.

I came from playing Strive and you can definitely see where the DNA for Strive came from with this game. A lot of small mechanics can be seen in both. But I will say that FighterZ is probably one of my top 3 fighting games. It has the spirit and action of Dragon Ball, the style you'd see from Strive, and just good feeling overall gameplay. 

All the characters are fun and unique to play, and the game is generally responsive. It feels great to hit combos and inputs, and I don't hate playing any of the characters. If you like Fighting Games, this one is super easy to recommend! (when it's on sale, which is often! The base game usually goes for -80% off, or $8.99usd!)

In a vortex of complete chaos and nothingness, a single Egg comes into being, which then hatches into Arceus, the first being in existence. Arceus then creates time, space, and anti-matter. Giratina, as punishment for its destructive nature, is sent by Arceus to live in the Distortion World. Dialga and Palkia then succeed in creating the universe and Pokémon world and retreat into their own dimensions afterwards, with a point of access being at the ancient Spear Pillar in Sinnoh.
Arceus then creates Uxie, Mesprit, and Azelf, giving knowledge, emotion, and willpower to all living things that come into existence in the Pokémon world. The three dive into caves at the bottom of Lake Verity, Lake Valor, and Lake Acuity in Sinnoh, giving them the name "lake guardians".
Kyogre is formed by the pressure in the deep sea trenches, Groudon is formed deep inside the Earth, likely from hardened magma and earth, and Rayquaza is formed by the minerals of the ozone layer. Rayquaza proceeds to fly around in the ozone layer, occasionally coming to rest at Sky Pillar.
Kyogre and Groudon then proceed to fill the sea and create land, respectively. A chance meeting turns the two into rivals, and a conflict for dominance over the Pokémon world begins. This battle continues until Rayquaza quells it, causing Kyogre and Groudon to retreat to special caverns, where they rest until the events of Generation III many years later. The Red and Blue Orbs are created to prevent the reawakening of Kyogre and Groudon, and are left at Mt. Pyre for safekeeping. At this time, Mew may have been plentiful and lived in large numbers.
Landmasses such as Mt. Coronet are created, and Regigigas moves the continents, forming the regions, and creates the three giants, Regirock, Regice, and Registeel, out of clay, ice, and magma, respectively.
The Sinnoh region is created around Mt. Coronet. During this violent procedure, Stark Mountain is created due to shifts in the crust of the world, and Heatran is formed in a pool of lava. Arceus creates the Adamant, Lustrous, and Griseous Orbs before falling into a deep slumber.
Prehistory
This information is based primarily on the study of Fossils and other archaeological remains. Some of this information is also based on scientific research.

Millions of years before Generation I:

The earliest known prehistoric Pokémon existed at this time. It is possible that the Mew population may have decreased at this stage, as they slowly gave way to other Pokémon species.
300 million years ago: An ancient version of Genesect was born. Kabuto and Kabutops lived in the sea.
Team Plasma later used Genesect's DNA to create an infinitely stronger version of it with cybernetic technology.
An unspecified hundreds of millions of years ago: Carbink begins its undisturbed underground sleep after its birth. It was born from deep underground temperatures and pressures.
100 million years ago: Species such as Aerodactyl, Lileep, Cranidos, Shieldon, Tirtouga, Archen, Tyrantrum and Amaura were supposedly widespread. They all ultimately went extinct, but not before Archen gave rise to bird Pokémon and Tirtouga gave rise to turtle Pokémon.
A Fossil is found millions of years later in Hoenn and revived scientifically by the Devon Corporation.
Shellder is known to be the prey of Omastar.
Carracosta and Archeops preyed on Omanyte. Only Carracosta is known to have eaten Omastar.
Relicanth is said to have remained unchanged for over 100 million years.
Anorith is stated to have existed in primordial seas, with its eight legs at some point developing into its known eight wings.
2,000,000 years ago: The Area Zero Underdepths may have been formed, according to Professor Sada/Turo.
1,000,000 years ago: The Great Crater of Paldea is created.
20,000 years ago:
A meteorite containing Eternatus fell in the Galar region.
The first Claydol was brought to life from a clay doll.
10,000 years ago:
During the last Ice Age, the Mamoswine population flourished, then decreased when the Ice Age ended.
Oldest known mural depictions of Cyclizar being ridden by humans.
At some point in the distant past, the Magikarp population mutates due to unknown reasons and becomes weaker.
At some point after the Iron Age, Regigigas is sealed away in the Snowpoint Temple, and Regirock, Regice, and Registeel are sealed away at various points across the Hoenn region after years of human worship.
5,000 years ago: Gogoat is domesticated & humans begin using them for transport.
3,000 years before Generation V:

The Relic items are created.
3,000 years before Generation VI:


AZ and the ultimate weapon
The Kalos war occurred, the ultimate weapon was created underneath Geosenge Town, and AZ was given eternal life.
3,000 years before Generation VIII:

A black storm called the Darkest Day occurred and was stopped by Zacian and Zamazenta.
Melmetal is worshipped by ancient humans for its ability to create metal from nothing.
2,500 years before Generation V:

The Relic Castle is built.
The Dragonspiral Tower is known as Unova's oldest structure, though its age is unstated.
2,000 years before Generation V:

Conkeldurr is said to have taught humans how to make concrete using centrifugal force.
2,000 years before Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire:

Hoenn is plagued by meteor showers. A meteor turns the homeplace of the Draconid people into Meteor Falls.
The world overflowed with natural energy which Groudon and Kyogre, in their primal forms, fought over. They ravaged the earth and were only calmed by Rayquaza after the Draconid people summoned it using a wish on a meteor at Meteor Falls. The people of Hoenn begin to revere Rayquaza as a savior.
2,000 years before Generation IX:

The Paldean Empire began to rule Paldea.
The emperor of Paldea ushers in the Great Age of Exploration by sending expeditions into The Great Crater of Paldea to find the treasure rumored to lie inside.
1,500 years before Generation I:

The earliest known system for writing is developed and used at the Ruins of Alph, Tanoby Ruins, and Solaceon Ruins. Archaeologists are currently unsure whether the nearly identical Unown preceded or succeeded the writing system, but it is assumed they share some sort of connection.
The Farfetch'd population decreases due to overhunting.
c. 1,000-2,000 years before Pokémon Legends: Arceus (c. 1,300-2,300 years before Generation IV):

An ancient society called the Celestica people lived in the Sinnoh region. They worshiped Arceus and built many structures which can still be found as ruins in the region in modern times, such as Solaceon Ruins, Snowpoint Temple, and Spear Pillar.
1,000 years before Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire:

A thousand years after the events at Meteor Falls, a meteor struck Hoenn, creating Sootopolis City. Groudon and Kyogre reawakened to fight over the wellspring of primal energy which came from it. The people of Hoenn wished on Rayquaza to save them, and using the meteor, Rayquaza performed the world's first Mega Evolution and calmed the two. Sky Pillar was built in Rayquaza's honor, and the Draconid people promised to pass down the prophecy that in 1,000 years the meteor would return - causing the events of the Delta Episode.
805 years before Generation IX:

Naranja AcademyS/Uva AcademyV is founded in Mesagoza.
800 years before X and Y:

Xerneas released life energy throughout the Kalos region and fled to a forest, where it went to sleep in the form of a tree.
Yveltal absorbed life energy throughout the Kalos region and fled to the mountains, where it went to sleep in the form of a cocoon.

The FitnessGram Pacer test is a multistage aerobic capacity test that progressively gets more difficult as it continues. The 20 meter Pacer test will begin in 30 seconds. Line up at the start. The running speed starts slowly, but gets faster each minute after you hear this signal *boop*. A single lap should be completed each time you hear this sound *ding*. Remember to run in a straight line, and run as long as possible. The second time you fail to complete a lap before the sound, your test is over. The test will begin on the word start. Dragon Ball FighterZ is an amazingly fun fighter and feels pretty manageable to the casual player - if you're like myself, who isn't particularly good at the genre, nor have played other similar titles like Marvel vs Capcom. 

The input execution for special moves is heavily simplified (involving only either quarter-circle-forward/backward motions) and jump cancel timing feels less tight compared to other anime fighters like BlazBlue. This is a good thing because long combo strings generally require chaining into air combo and they are relatively easier to execute here. For the record, I can never quite pull off long combo strings in BlazBlue regardless of how much I practice. But I can do pretty long combos in this game with lesser time spent in training mode and still feel I can get better.

There are also auto-combos (by mashing Light or Medium attacks) which are inherently part of the combo system - imo, I feel they are well-implemented. Auto-combos have certain properties like auto positioning closer to the opponent, making it easier to pull off air combo chains. For e.g. a basic ground-to-air combo like 2M, M, JC, L, M, JC, L, M, H can also be done as 2M, M, JC, L x2, JC, L x3. The latter will be easier to pull off, and that's not just because it requires fewer mixing of inputs but simply because of the auto-positioning itself. The great thing I feel about this is that even if an entry level player uses auto-combos as a crutch, he/she still needs to get into the habit of fairly precise inputs instead of just button mashing (since the latter combo requires hitting L the exact number of times). I think this is a good way to enable a new player to do something complex in a easier manner and condition them with the right habits at the same time.

If I have any complaints about the game, they would be:
- The story mode (which makes up the bulk of single-player content) and its plot are kinda meh.
- The tutorials are not really that useful.
- [strike]The OST is largely forgettable, though there are a few tracks that I fancy - like Bardock's and Android 16's themes.[/strike]


The game is heavily discounted so you should get either the FighterZ or Ultimate Edition when on sale.
Both editions include only the FighterZ Pass 1 (8 additional characters) while the latter includes additional commentator and music tracks if you care about that. Personally, I got the FighterZ edition as the music tracks don't appeal to me. 

Strongly recommended!

Edit: I take back what I said about the OST. After occasional listening to various themes on Youtube over the course of time, I think I actually do like the OST quite a fair bit. The two I mentioned are probably still my favorites but there are at least 7 others I've come to love.

Like most fighting games, DBFZ is most fun:
[b](A)[/b] When you have friends who [i][b]want[/b][/i] to play with you, [b]OR[/b]
[b](B)[/b] If you take the game seriously enough to compete and/or play the online mode.

If you have [b](A)[/b] or [b](B)[/b], go wild & enjoy!  
You are probably already a fan of fighting games and you will enjoy what the game has to offer. 
There is more than enough depth to keep you and your friends busy. 

BUT, [i]If you [b]don't[/b] have [b](A)[/b] or [b](B)[/b], then I [b]do not[/b] recommend buying this game.[/i]

[b]1.[/b] The online is horrible.
[b]2.[/b] The DLC structure is horrible.
[b]3.[/b] The "campaign" and other PvE elements are not worth mentioning.

Although it is relatively easy for beginners to [i]get into[/i] this game due to auto-combos, and the graphics/animations are very pleasing to the senses, once you peel back the onion it is just like any other fighting game wherein it is very difficult & frustrating to compete against someone with a skill disparity.  You need to dedicate a LOT of time in order to fully appreciate & understand the cast of characters and how they play in battle (outside of tapping Light Attack ad nauseam).  [b]If you don't have the time, you will never enjoy the game and you will waste your money.[/b] 

Yes, this is basically true of virtually any fighting game, but in DBFZ it is especially true.  DBFZ is very fast and unforgiving (for better or for worse, depending on the skill disparity).  This does not bode well with the online play, which, again, is absolutely horrible.   So, unless you and your friend(s) are relatively matched in skill/knowledge, AND you are local, you probably won't play for very long before someone quits out of frustration, helplessness, or boredom.

Once you give up on trying to convince your friends to play, you are then stuck trying to compete online.  And, well, like I said, the online is horrible.

TL;DR: Dragonball FighterZ was Marvel when we needed it most.

Honestly, this isn't really a review. I just need a space to say my piece here, because there's so much I can say about this game. From launch to current version, so much has changed.

I'm speaking to the other folks with a few hundred or thousand hours in here - Remember when A16 got a hard knockdown from a command grab? Remember watching Bardock's super 4 times every set? Remember when people thought Z Broly was bad? Remember the menaces of Kid Goku, UI Goku, Fusions? Remember Labcoat (not like you'd have to dig very deep)? Do you remember how much your characters changed, from patch to patch? Do you remember going back to an old team and feeling nostalgic? Do you remember reading patch notes and feeling like you were so betrayed, or so uplifted? Do you remember when she said "rollback" - and before the translator could even think about speaking - the crowd exploded? Do you remember cell screams?

I apologize for being so sentimental in a literal steam review, but damn man, this game showed me that every hour you put into a fighting game can be an hour you get out. I'll admit, the IP does make it. Even your dad knows Goku. But that's all part of it. I never really did comics or their movies/shows/related media, but I did watch Toonami. I did watch Krillin explode. I did play Budokai, Xenoverse, the WORKS trying to feel like I was a super saiyan, chasing some kind of high. Nothing came close to DBFZ. I feel like a fucking warrior playing this game.

It's not for everyone. Absolutely not. It's SO hard to get your homies on discord to play the stupid unlimited gokus fighting game with you. But for what it was and what it did for me, this game is my GOAT. The bar everything else will be held to. I feel so lucky I had it, have it, and will have it (WITH ROLLBACK!) in the future. I will be playing this game in the nursing home. I will be playing it if and when my consciousness separates from my body. And I'll probably play it today, too.

Unless you're a frame perfect autists, just don't bother. It offers ZERO leniency for combos and the roster is quite pay to win. Plus, there's the problem of new players, (Myself included) have to deal with. Experienced players. The skill ceiling is so high in this game it's damn near unplayable online. Enjoy never winning a match against anybody who's been playing since launch or at least a few years. There is ZERO casual play. The frame perfect requirement for even the most basic of combos will shut down most players out the gate. I'd consider myself average in other fighting games like Soulcalibur or Tekken, but those are more combo forgivable with longer airtimes and "slower" gameplay and can be played casually with no issue because of this.

This game, has zero casualability. You either play and train for hours a day, or you never properly pick it up... I love DBZ and watching the videos from this game, but I would not recommend it for newer players.

Getting this game to work on the Steam Deck has so far been a pain. The people in the forums say it's possible, it just doesn't work in Online Mode because the anti-cheat doesn't work in Linux. Which is fine, my goal was set up multiplayer matches like it is 2004 and I'm renting Budokai 3 from Blockbuster to play at my friend's house on the PS2. I think I may have gotten it to work but had to reboot due to the game being in windowed mode on the TV and the now it won't launch because it can't verify my purchase and I have to wait 24 hours. 

Yup. Doing tech support on a steam deck used up all the activation tokens of the anti-pirate program and locked me out for 24 hours. At this rate I'm probably going to return this game. 

Also, massive sale five years after the game is released and it's still 50 dollars to get all the character DLCs and that required research to figure out to make sure I got them all.

First off, best competitive DB game I've ever played. Played about 400 hrs on the ps4 as well so, I have around I guess 900 or so of game play. Easily the most fun I've had with a DB game since either BT2 or Burst Limit. Played when the game dropped, but didn't play for a while since season 3. Lately played with some friends and wanted figured I'd write a review since some of my buddy's started doing there own. This is going to be long, so brace yourselves.   

 A fun fighting game to learn for beginners. Inputs are simple by comparison to other games, yet there still plenty of combo variety where execution can be real difficult. If your looking for a challenge in combo execution, this game has for you. The trainer in lobby can teach some of the mechanics in the game, and they added another trainer as well that goes over more. There have been plenty of mechanics changes since release, which some have reduced issues that made it harder to deal with game-play situations in matches. Such has made characters be more viable to play, but at the risk of reducing options offensively. It's arguable either way whether it was good or not to do such, but I would never say it took away form the fun of the game.

Of the mechanics that are something to mention and that is sparking. Sparking is a useful tool that generally gets used in three ways;  use to get out of pressure to keep from losing a character, for comebacks for the anchor or just the last remaining character, because its remains for a longer period of time, and increases damage, or to gain the damage increase to finish an opponents character. You can also jump cancel from your normal inputs, adding to the combo variety and mix-up options you can use. It also regenerates some of lost heath in blue and gives extra meter than you get normally. Spark can be used while your blocking which is a change they made season 2 I believe, but cannot be used when getting combo'd like in some other Arcsys games. I would say that by comparison, this game is a bit more fair defensively with some situations you'll run into by comparison with the other games like MVC where assist can hit you low, making potential unblockable situations.

There's also the story mode {which has its ups and downs} and an arcade mode, both increasing in difficulty the further you get. Story mode has a leveling system increasing character stat values and items that aid you in fight. Downside in both of these is..the AI is FUCKED UP with how much damage it can do to you! Generally it will hit you once than if it has meter to spend, will super for high amount of damage. Its really frustrating when you'll have a near full health character, is around 30%. If it did a combo, it'd be less annoying maybe, but just...geez. Otherwise, the story mode does drag a bit. There are some fun character interactions in cut scenes, Depending on who is in the team and more. There are hilarious and great moments that you can just look up on YouTube if your interested. 

Online is where the actions is with other players and man! The connections  can be good to HORRENDOUS. This is the games biggest issue to the detriment of its longevity, and has remained such since release. When you do have a solid connection, matches can be fun. However, connections can fluctuate which is annoying as hell making it increasing more difficult to play matches or even want to play at all at times.

As far as getting into matches, here is a Fair warning; don't be shocked if you get steamrolled. Games been out for over 4 years, and the players are gonna play with intention to win. You can of course set that you want to play people by rank, but I'm not sure how many people play in the lower ranks which you could either be just sitting there or it could match you with someone more relative to your rank. Still, don't be discourage, there are plenty of people and communities willing to teach beginners. There is also boss run which you play a single character on a team with other players against ridiculous AI that happens occasionally and you can there is 3v3 styles against another set of players which is fun to play with friends. There is the arena in the middle of the lobby area that has gimmick matches you can play which seem like they can be a lot of fun, but I don't remember seeing alot of people playing them that much nor played them myself. 

Had so much fun playing this game and its one of 2 fighting games I've spent the 500 hours in. I doubt at this point that this game will get rollback to help with the online issues, but I have hopes if they do have a sequel to this game that it won't have this issue. Especially after the release of Strive and rollback being added to there other games which has gained interest towards all of them. Recently Lab Coat came out and what maybe the last update is coming and could help some characters a buff or 2. That also means this we are coming to the finished state of this game now and I loved it regardless of my own complaints. This was great game and is one my favorite fighting games that I have played.

I put hundreds of hours on the xbox version on Dragonball fighterz. I switched to pc and have continued to play. 
Campaign is terrible and I wouldn't play it even if you paid me. Story, writing, and structure are awful. Some character interactions are great like Gohan meeting Perfect Cell in his mystic form. However this isn't anywhere near enough motivation for me to play through this campaign.

Gameplay: Outstanding. Great for new comers with auto combos and a simple controller scheme for players to pick up. Characters may seem homogeneous at first but experimenting with different teams and understanding the move sets of various characters allow for 1000's of hours of labbing. 
Sound/Music. Great all around. Voice acting for both Japanese and English are exactly what you expect if you have watched the anime. Music tracks are a mixed bag.
Graphics/Performance. Runs perfectly fine on my system and everything looks faithful to the anime and even better in areas. ARC knows anime and with the experience with Guilty Gear shows in spades here.
Online is not great. The inferior delay based netcode is a chore to deal with. Finding red bar connections and fighting the same few people over and over again in ranked make for a terrible experience. However with the announcement and beta tests with the delay based netcode actually have me hyped to play the online mode once again.
Overall good game. 7/10 in current state. 8/10 with the netcode

This is coming from someone who mainly plays non-competitively, as in I usually fight level 100 AI and then maybe players sometimes.

I am aware of the balancing issues of some characters though such as SSJ4 (Both SSJ4 and SSJB Gogeta), broly and a few others. this game isn't really "perfect" in balancing but PvP has been fun if you're not fighting against those meta characters.

The game's combat is actually extremely good. I didn't even notice this was developed by the same dudes at Arc (Same people who created GG:S) so that's already a great merit to it. the artstyle is amazing given how hard it's been for many studios to transfer the anime style to 3D, this had very nice eye candy and many references to the source material, with dramatic finishes being re-animated scenes from the show / movies, and i think that's a nice touch for those very familiar with DBZ. I didn't actually purchase this as a DBZ fan and wanted to try a fighting game like this, this was on sale too so i figured why not.

The DLC locks quite a few characters, some being extremely fun to play and others being... ok. The base cast of characters are still good to play and enjoyable.

Even if I didn't touch PvP much, I actually had a lot of fun with its combat system and the assist mechanic which allowed other characters to tag in shortly to use a single attack and whatnot. It's a very fun game regardless of whether you're familiar with the DBZ IP or not.

I brought it to play online mode but player base has decreased drastically. i like the fact that its challenging to be an average player you need to master combos which is difficult

DBFZ is a game nearing it's end stages, if not at it. New players, casual players or returning players should avoid the game even though rollback is announced a lifeline measure. Honestly the game is simple and straight forward, but has too many interactions and mechanics to keep an eye for, for casual players who cannot spend several hours on the game on a daily basis. The game rewards those who keep practice everyday in and out every combo or TOD. Matchmaking is a joke as most matches in lower ranks just hit a wall when actually getting matched against higher ranked players. Additionally the matchmaking takes too long for lower ranks; probably because there have been no new players in the game or lower purchases. Don't get me wrong, DBFZ allows for high skill expression, yet is resoundingly oppressive against those that do not constantly play the game. Sure, you can just say get better or git gud, but sometimes it is better to play others games like Terraria or Stardew Valley to relax than stress out on a fighting game. Although I have played around 90 hours the fun gotten is very little, but the amount of stress is considerable. Returning players or casual players should not even bother with this game anymore given the high requirement of time spent in it to even have some fun.

[UPDATE 1] Its been 1K more hours later. still no rollback.

[UPDATE 2] Rollback is a government psyop. [/strike]

[UPDATE 3 - THE ROLLBACK BETA TEST] 2,168 hours later, yes you heard that right.
The Pros:
Online has never felt this smooth.
I'm able to play against players from Central-East Canada (I am US South West) with little to no delay/rollback frames. Have not tested with European players but from what I heard is that its playable, but not ideal. Japanese/Korean players have a great connection however.

The cons:
- the continuously flashing character icons mid match are not only distracting, but they flash so often it [b]could[/b] be considered a epilepsy hazard.

- the KO screens are bugged, nothing insane or bothersome who are here for the gameplay, but for people who like the overall aesthetic of the game will definitely find it annoying.

- ring lobby matches have a chance to disconnect when someone is spectating, should be fixed by the time rollback officially releases.

Overall, I've never been more happy with the game. The rollback is so buttery smooth (so smooth and fast that a lot of players I've been talking to are considering turning on button delay to match PS4/tournament standard delay.)

The beta ends on December 10th. I do not recommend buying the game after the beta is over or until a sale presents itself. But when that happens, this game is an instant buy for both casual Dragon Ball fans and casual/competitive fighting game players. The meta is in a weird but interesting place where every character is playable to a certain degree. Obviously the stronger characters at the moment will still dominate but its not nearly as bad as the Fusion/Labcoat meta, which made a good 60% of the cast non viable.

Again, when rollback is officially added as an update and not a beta, or a sale presents itself.

This is the fighting game that got me into fighting games. I put about 250 hours on console and now almost 200 on PC.

The satisfaction of hitting combo strings you've been practicing is AMAZING, and it definitely helps that the combos in this game are so flashy. I found myself actually having a good time just going into practice mode to mess around, learn new characters, and look up optimal combos to practice with my favorites.

If you are new to fighting games, or a Dragon Ball fan, I highly recommend giving this game a shot, ESPECIALLY now that rollback is out, it makes online a lot smoother. I hope more people get to experience this game the way I have, and have as much fun as I do getting some friends to hop on and run some ring matches still to this day. <3

Okay nostalgia trip, but extremely unapproachable.

Story mode is a blatant attempt to stretch out play time with a very grindy, repetitive "beat up all these guys" simulator, with rare cutscenes peppered in. Granted, these scenes are great and offer a relief from the dull gameplay, but the gameplay is kinda the important part. PvE difficulty alternates between laughably easy enemies who don't know how to block and being combo'd for half of your health, seemingly at random. You will trash 9/10 opponents on a map, but 1 will randomly decide it's been too easy on you and just annihilate you for a minute, before seemingly forgetting how to block again.

The UI is clunky and feels like it was ported from a console, rather than actually designed for PC. Just opening the lobby takes multiple loading screens, which are repeated every time you change modes. Want to quit out of the game from Story Mode? Save Game -> Leave story mode -> wait for loading screens to reload lobby -> Quit -> wait for the title screen to load -> Quit

Then there's matchmaking, where there seems to be no difference between "I have been playing this game daily for 5 years" and "I'm new and looking to learn how to play". Matches appear to be a combo competition where the battle has been decided after the first few blows. Either there are no longer new players to match with or the system does not make an effort to differentiate skill levels.

This is a game that has as much potential as you're willing to put into it, but you really need to bring your own friends to play with too.

My only negative is that the single player gameplay modes are lacking. The campaign is repetitive and grindy. It's not terrible, but if you stick to single player content you'll be missing out on the best the game has to offer. 

I'd criticize the online here, but ROLLBACK IS HERE BAYBEE!!!! 

As a whole I very strongly recommend it. It's one of my favorite games ever and I love it with all my heart. DBFZ has pushed me further than any other fighting game ever and i'm so excited to play more of it with the rollback update.

The games fun, love the 3v3 tag system, love the arcade mode, love the assists, just love the game.
It's even more fun when you know how to play your characters and how the game fully works...

So much of it is less learn how to actually do things than it is "Force a guard, miss your attack intentionally"
Why would I want to intentionally miss to leave myself open when I can just wait .2 seconds to actually connect the attack and continue a combo?

10/10

I am rewriting this review that I have much more experience in the game, and have even reached the ranked SSJ3 on the ranked ladder, and played in a tournament since this came out.

To start off, despite having a few fighting games between all my systems, I've never really be that great at them. I just don't have much of a patience for sitting down to learn the combos, and end up being terrible because it. But with this game, it was never a problem for me. I don't know why, maybe it's because it's Dragon Ball, and I grew up with most of the cast, and love Team Four Star. It just clicked with me.

That being said, this game is easily 10/10. It has very solid 3v3 fighting game mechanics similar to, but not as broken as, UMvC3. The game is extremely easy to pick up, and is very newbie friendly. I don't think I'd ever be able to climb as high as I have in any other fighting game. This game is the perfect balance between "I have no idea what I'm doing" and "esports level plays." It's fast paced, Dragon Ball action, with the perfect look for a Dragon Ball game. While it isn't quite a 100% recreation of the Dragon Ball fights in the anime, it is still the most fun I've had in both a fighting game, and in a Dragon Ball game. Nothing has topped this to this date, and I this game is a solid addition to any fighting game collection anyone could have, and probably won't disapear until a sequal comes out.

a lot of fun! if you're real into dragon ball there's a lot of neat callbacks or references or whatever, going through the series after having played this game a while made for a good time pointing out moments and going "Oh shit that's goku's 2S!" there's lot of love in this game and it shows.
plays pretty well. even just moving around feels really good, and all the mechanics come together well. basically all of the characters have at least something interesting going on, which can actually make it hard to settle on a team when so many of the options work for you (non-issue).
singleplayer content isn't great? the story mode is pretty boring, bots with cranked up damage are mostly just annoying to play against and the story itself isn't anything special. multiplayer has the caveat of still being on delay-based netcode for the time being, and it's filled with really annoying players.
the balance also kind of blows. the game's been powercrept to hell, to the point where if you want to spend the resources you can TOD with basically anyone in pretty realistic circumstances. a lot of characters have frustrating tools they can skip neutral with and brutal mixups that are hard to even see through all the visual noise you get with assists, it really gets out of hand. i guess all characters are viable? so if you're a big tien fan you don't necessarily have to toss that away to play 3 versions of goku and/or vegeta, but the good characters are still stupid good.
still, there's a lot of fun to have with the game, and it's definitely worth the pretty low price it goes on sale for. maybe not -all- the dlc? buying pass 2 & 3 alongside the fighterZ edition with pass 1 ends up, like, quadrupling the (on sale) price. it's not like you're really gonna play every one of these guys, anyways. but the base game is 100% worth it, even if you aren't necessarily a fan of the series.

So I mostly play this on my switch, but it doesn't really change this review.

This game is the best looking Dragon Ball game you will ever play. The 2.5d cell shaded style is so pleasing to the eyes. The cinematic sequences in the games add a ton of "holey crap" moments. Overall, this game is extremely visually appealing.

Gameplay is tons of fun. The fact that newer players can mash and feel like they are doing something is always great to see. Press X repeatedly to do a cool combo. Let it be known it that this doesn't give you an advantage in online matches. If you mash, you will lose. Knowing combos, timing, frame data, spacing, and inputs will beat out mashing every time.

Characters feel unique and there are plenty of them to choose from. Heck there are 5 or 6 Gokus to choose from. You'll definitely find your favorite character to play or maybe even a character you never heard of before. And with the tag based system, you get to bring 3 of your favorites into battle. 

The game is always active, probably because its Dragon Ball, so you will always see someone online.

Now with all that out of the way lets talk about some negatives. 

The game has been out for....a while. Most players online have been playing since the beginning and are very experienced in the game. So, finding a match can take a while for ranked modes. And, for unranked...good luck. You could get paired with a brand new player or a max ranked veteran. 

I also feel that each character has optimal combos and if you aren't pulling them off, then you aren't gonna win with the current players. If you try to experiment with different combos, you're going to be in for a bad time. You'll see several players doing the same combos for specific characters. Not really a big negative, but something I found to be a little sad. 

The game may be easy to get into, but you'll struggle online unless you put in the time to learn your characters and their combos. This goes for any fighting game, but I feel it's more prevalent here. So if you want to win, do some studying and practice your combos religiously.

Over all, the game is great and worth picking up!

Dragon Ball FighterZ is an absolute triumph in the realm of competitive fighting games. As a lifelong Dragon Ball fan and a gaming enthusiast, this title left me thoroughly impressed and deeply satisfied. From its stunning visuals to its intricate gameplay mechanics, Dragon Ball FighterZ is a must-play for fans of the series and fighting game aficionados alike.

Graphics and Presentation: 5/5
The visuals in Dragon Ball FighterZ are nothing short of spectacular. The developers have captured the essence of the anime with stunning, cel-shaded graphics that make it feel like you're controlling the characters directly from the TV screen. The attention to detail in character animations and the impressive recreation of iconic scenes from the series are breathtaking. It truly feels like you're part of the Dragon Ball world.

Gameplay: 4.5/5
The combat system in Dragon Ball FighterZ is both accessible for newcomers and deep enough to satisfy seasoned fighting game enthusiasts. The controls are intuitive, allowing for a smooth learning curve. The combo system is robust, and mastering it is incredibly rewarding. Each character feels unique, and the game offers a good balance of offensive and defensive strategies, making for engaging and varied matches. However, the only minor downside is that the learning curve for some of the more advanced mechanics can be a bit steep.

Character Roster: 5/5
The game boasts an impressive and diverse roster of Dragon Ball characters, including fan favorites like Goku, Vegeta, Piccolo, and Frieza, as well as more obscure choices like Beerus and Hit. Each character feels true to their anime counterpart and has a distinct playstyle, making for exciting matchups. The DLC characters introduced over time only add to the excitement, giving the game a great sense of longevity.

Single-Player Content: 4/5
While the main attraction of Dragon Ball FighterZ is its multiplayer battles, the single-player content, including the story mode, offers a substantial and enjoyable experience. The story mode is engaging, featuring an original storyline with excellent character interactions and epic battles. However, some of the battles can be a bit repetitive.

Multiplayer and Community: 5/5
The heart of any great fighting game lies in its online multiplayer, and Dragon Ball FighterZ does not disappoint. The netcode is top-notch, resulting in minimal lag and seamless online battles. The game's competitive community is thriving, with frequent tournaments and updates keeping the experience fresh and competitive.

In conclusion, Dragon Ball FighterZ is an absolute gem for fans of the series and the fighting game genre. Its stunning visuals, diverse character roster, accessible yet deep gameplay, and strong community support make it a game that can be enjoyed for years to come. Whether you're a Dragon Ball enthusiast or just a fighting game enthusiast, this title is a knockout powerhouse that should not be missed. Kamehameha your way into the action and experience the thrill for yourself!

[h1]It's time for DBFZ to retire[/h1]
[b][u]Score: 2/10[/u][/b]
[hr][/hr]
DBFZ was a game that united the Fighting game community. When it first released, you saw pro players from all different games come to this one in particular to duke it out. New players, who never even touched a fighting game, also chose this as their first, myself included. This game's aggressive play style, beautiful visuals and easy to pick up, hard to master game play, all backed up by a giant franchise that everyone has at least heard of before, made it so that no matter how experienced you were with fighting games, you were drawn to this one. That's how it started, at least.

Over the years, Dragon ball fighterZ has morphed into something completely different, when you compare it to how it started out. I've played this game for a loooong time and I stopped right around the end of season 3. I had several issues with the game, that made it not enjoyable in the end. In ranked, you would see the same 5 or so characters over and over again. Around the time there were also characters released as DLC, who were completely broken and stayed that way for many weeks, before finally getting nerfed. Combine that with weird balancing patches and just better, more fun games coming out and I lost interest in this one. I recently got some youtube videos recommended of this game and wanted to check it out again.

So, what is the game like right now? It's been over a year and a half, since the last DLC character was released and patches for this game are few and far between. Rollback, a great net code that makes even the worst of connections at least somewhat playable, is apparently coming, it was promised many months ago and we still haven't heard any news about it. I was quite excited to come back to this game, after so long. However, I felt sorely disappointed. I know that this entire review, seems like I'm some sort of old lady reminiscing about the days of old, but that is how I truly feel. I think the developers pushed this game too far. Right now, the game is very broken. All characters can seemingly do everything and the game became very brain dead. I can't take it seriously as a competitive fighting game, but I also can't enjoy it in the same way as a broken, silly fighting game, where you laugh with friends about how stupid the things happening in the game are, something like SF 2 Rainbow edition, or the different turbo mods for smash games. To me, the game is stuck in this weird middle ground, where it's too broken and brain dead to be enjoyed competitively, but also too boring to be enjoyed with friends. I think it's time for DBFZ to retire. It was fun while it lasted, but all things must come to an end.

Dragon Ball FighterZ, where the "Z" stands for "Zany Zuper Ztuff." If you've ever dreamt of settling the age-old debate of who would win in a fight between Goku and, say, a large green Namekian or an android with a mad scientist's haircut, this game is your answer. And it's like an intergalactic WWE match on steroids!

Pros:

Non-stop action: Remember those moments in the anime when they'd stare intensely at each other for five episodes before throwing a single punch? Yeah, you won't find that here. It's a relentless brawl from start to finish.
Ridiculously powerful moves: Unleash the power of the Dragon Balls, and watch your enemies cower in fear as you summon Shenron. Just don't wish for "more fighters," or it'll break the game.
Over 9000 nostalgia points: This game will transport you back to your childhood when you attempted (unsuccessfully) to go Super Saiyan in your backyard.
Saiyan Hair: The ultimate power of Saiyans? Gravity-defying hair. Just wait until you see your fighters' locks go wild during a match.
Cons:

Button mashing mayhem: You might start out with strategy, but the chaos quickly devolves into frantic button mashing. "Hadouken" or "Kamehameha"? Who cares, just mash everything!
Learning curve: If you want to master all the combos and special moves, prepare for a steeper learning curve than Goku's power level.
Absurdly long attack animations: When Cell does his solar flare or Frieza decides to chat for five minutes, you might find yourself wondering if you can order a pizza in between.
In the end, Dragon Ball FighterZ is like a giant Dragon Ball-themed carnival, and you're invited to the wildest party in the universe. Whether you're a die-hard DBZ fan or just someone looking for over-the-top anime brawling, it's a blast! Just be prepared for the button mashing madness and the occasional existential question: "Do I want to win this fight or see another transformation animation?"

Game's kind of a joke, but fun if you manage to find friends to play with. For starters if you want a friendly battle or want to try other types of modes you can forget about it because no one plays anything but serious fight on ring match, rare times I find a match labeled friendly and no times have I ever seen anyone trying to host any other modes so kind of lackluster. Personally I'd prefer more variety in my playing if I'm going to play with other people. Gets old rather quickly if no one on there has a wider range of preferences.

Aside from that, you can't change your region from what I can see after you pick your region, so if you pick a region and then decided you rather try playing with a different crowd from a different part of the world you can't, you're trapped in whatever region you chose. The battle stages you can pick from are limited and while you can thankfully play as certain characters that are normally only playable via unlocking in other games, the roster is still pretty pathetic. Beerus is in it, but Champa is not, yet we have Goku's whole family and even fusions. 

Also if you don't like toxicity and thought the preset chat style would save you from having to deal with it, you've thought wrong, because people still find ways to be toxic/unsportsmanlike using the preset chat. The cosmetics are done in a Gacha  style way, which would be fine if you feel like grinding for days to get zeni, but if you're a casual player and only play every now and then you will likely never gain the cosmetics you want without throwing away a lot of your time and hardearned zeni to hope you get it.

Finally, my last complaint about this game is just that using the controls are difficult. While I'm sure most of us who played this game, probably have had our share of combo fighting mortal combat type games, the control in this game are particularly unintuitive when compared to other games of this similar genre.

Bottom line, don't get it unless part of your fun comes in the form of being an absolute masochist with only one game mode you like. Have a good day.

Matchmaking is horrific - ranked will have smurfs crush you and casual match will set you against people completely out of your league.

Getting locked into a long combo by an opponent while the game does nothing to teach you how to prevent it or where your counterstrike point would be. Need to spend an entire university degree's worth of effort learning the tinest details of each single character so you don't spend most of a match getting smashed into the corner with no way of getting out.

Update: Many hours later, the game's problems remain the same. Ranked Match is the only way to get anything remotely fair, but this is not guaranteed when you have people smurfing in the lower levels. Casual Match is utterly unplayable - you only ever see top end players who can kill each of your characters in 1-2 combos. At that point, you might as well just go play Fantasy Strike instead.

Game badly needs some form of options to help players who don't have the time or skill to master these combos. An option to lower the damage you take from combos while lowering the damage you deal with them. But they won't, so the game has sunk into a rut like many fighting games before it - the only ones left will destroy new players so thoroughly they'll just give up and play something else, all while complaining that the game is dying.

EDIT: I've tried this game on and off over the last 2 years and came back again with the recent update. My view of the game is unchanged. When you actually get a similarly skilled opponent and the game does not lag to hell, it's a genuinely good fighting game. But that's not what happens 90% of the time.

What mostly happens is you get dunked on by smurfs in ranked. You, with your 45% win rate and nearly a thousand games total, vs someone of the same rank with only 50 games. Yet the opponent earns barely any extra points in order to rapidly get them out of a rank they are clearly outclassing. Winstreaks badly need to multiply the ranking points in order to get smurfs back into their proper brackets and allow lower skilled players to actually enjoy the online component, especially because...

"Casual Match" - possibly the worst case of false advertising i've seen in years. There are no casuals left in a fighting game of this age. The only opponent you will get is a top tier tournament level player who can dunk on you in 2 combos with each character and perform all sorts of techniques like crossups that you can't deal with. Even when it's become obvious their opponent is far below them, they don't tone things down to let the "casual" match actually be enjoyable. They will happily go full sweaty palm tryhard every single match. It's completely offputting to newer or lesser skilled players and it makes them quit.

Then they cry about their communities being dead.

'FighterZ' emerges as a veritable magnum opus, a tour de force of kinetic artistry that tantalizingly marries finesse with ferocity. The combat mechanics, a harmonious blend of strategy and spontaneity, offer an exhilarating dance of pixels that is nothing short of intoxicating. Each bout is a symphony of calculated moves, a ballet of punches and parries that beckons the player into its rhythmic embrace.

However, a word of caution to the discerning gamer: this is not a mere dalliance. Engage in this digital duel with friends, and you may find them metamorphosing into relentless tryhards, consumed by the siren call of competition. Such is the allure of 'FighterZ' that, once ensnared, one is compelled to ascend the echelons of mastery, dedicating countless hours to perfecting one's craft. If you dare to embark on this journey, do so with eyes wide open, for you and your comrades will inevitably be drawn into a vortex of relentless ambition, striving for supremacy in every match.
