ok so, as you might see, I have more than 1k hours in this game, even though I don't recommend it.
you could say it's the kind of game which you love as much as you hate it. let me explain:
for the good things:
- the gameplay and combo routes.
It's by far my most prefered gameplay of every fighting games I've played so far. easy to start, and still really hard to master. with that every characters feels really unique but if you still like to change characters often (which is usually hard in fighting games) you can by learning some universals basics (though it wont be enough ofc to learn what your new character can really do with advanced combos).
So yes, the gameplay is trully amazing and that's why I have more than 1k hours on this game.
BUT, now, let's talk about why I still don't recommend this game, THE CONS:
- no content:
by that I mean, when you play solo, you have almost nothing to do (and some might say "hey it's a fighting game ofc you have not much to do in solo" ... go see what Mortal kombat can do, yes fighting games can have solo modes, and good ones).
Then you have nothing to unlock by playing, I mean nothing worth your time: the only thing you can unlock after getting all characters is : new music tracks (which are rlly bad for 80% of those), new lobby characters (= useless) and ... new colors for your playable characters ... yes ... colors ... you can have a new skin to customise even a little your favourite characters, only colors ...
Yes I'm maybe asking a lot to add some real skins but think about it, when you have nothing to do in solo, nothing to unlock ... yes the only thing you can do is train your combos in training mode, spar with a friend or go online ... nowadays that's not enough at all.
- Bad support from Devs:
another bad thing about this, Devs are really like REALLY bad at communicating anything, that and giving us like 1 or 2 worth updates each year (basically this game is quite abandonned by devs so).
If you don't believe me, just look on the internet about the famous "roll back net code" the devs promised us for way longer than a year ago, and still nothing ...

SO yes, I do play a lot this game, sadly I can't recommend it unless you get it for like 5 Euros or so, or if you have a really good friend to play with and sparing with the 2 of you will be enough.
If you go solo, don't buy it, some others fightings games have a way better content (like SF6 and upcoming MK1 for example) and will be hopefully more supported by their devs.

After 650+ hours in the game, I've finally achieved it. 
You might've heard it from others before, but Goku is literally me, for real.
I spent so much time in the hyperbolic time chamber, that I can do exactly what Goku does. 
This includes:
- Getting into fistfights with various gay-looking aliens from across the universe.
- Coming home to my country bumpkin of a wife who better fucking have dinner ready.
- Completely ignoring my children. If they want my attention they'll have to fight me for it.
- Being able change form, powering up into Ryan Gosling from the Barbie Movie. I am Kenough.
- Having the metabolism of a 20 year old, while actually being around 50. Fusion Dancing the food into my very being.

As far as the game, it's fun. 
Netcode's kinda jank. Perhaps they'll fix it.

Ok first of all- Arcworks, the developer of this game, makes the animation of Dragonball Z look 10 times better than the TV show even though all of the content in this game still comes directly from the TV show. 

That being said, 80% of the joy I get from this game is the eye candy visuals. Although I respect the jagged-edged pixel th 16bit history of 2D cartoon fighters.. there's something to be said when a game can make a crisp sharp 3D rendered environment look indistinguishable from a 2D game. Arcworks knows their craft well, and I consider them to be the pioneers of cel-shading in video games. Every other game that attempts to make Dragonball Z work as a 3D game but look 2D like the show still have those technical struggles to make it look truly 2D... Arcworks does it like a science. 

On to the gameplay. The cool thing about this game is that the range of skill and approachability of this game were designed for both kids and hardcore fighting game enthusiasts. Don't ask me how it was done, but it seems like the focus of this game was to allow a kid to pick it up and play their heart out and still do "Goku stuff" while a hardcore competitive player can play this game and make it as technical as desired at the same time. 

Much like Nintendo's 'Smash bros.' was enjoyed by your 5 year cousin while you also lost adult friendships from sweat lording hang outs, this game combines easy to use fighting techniques with serious competitive range to appease all crowds and fans of a franchise to come together and enjoy the experience alike. 

If you are even a half fan of the DBZ franchise you will love this fighting game. 

The only downside is the DLC cucking they do on letting you have all the cool fighters without paying 50$ extra.

Fighting games have never been my thing. But hey, it's Dragon Ball with animations even better than the actual show! If that wasn't enough the e-Sports scene around this game is so hype. I just couldn't help myself and I watched tons of pro matches and learned all about the deep, intricate technicalities behind fighting games like DBFZ. 

The community around this game is great, so much content online to enjoy and to learn from. And the game itself is very solid, with lots to enjoy in both single player and online modes. For single player, the main activity is going to be story mode and for a DBZ game, the story is decent. Just don't expect too much. For online play, you'll be doing ranked matches and improving in the practice lab. The lab is excellent and let's you set up any situation that you want to practice. Just beware that you'll need to buy the DLC characters or you won't be able to practice with or against them in the lab. It's not strictly necessary but if you're serious about climbing the ranks you'll definitely need to unlock characters that are popular in the meta.

There's much more to say but I think this covers the general points I wanted to share. If DBZ is totally your thing, you really should play this title.

Dragonball Fighterz proves to be an excellent replacement in my life for that fast paced, hardcore explosive action in a fighting game. It handles like Ultimate Marvel Versus Capcom 3, looks graphically like the BEST Anime fighter out there today, and absolutely  keeps me coming back. I can't say any other fighting game has lent as much fun to me as Fighterz has, and I continue to come back to see the occasional fun bout of what ifs involved in it's roster. With fantastic music, an excellent roster of characters, and a fantastic player base, I can confidently give Fighterz a solid 8/10. The lack of Rollback means that many a professional player's experience may be hampened, but overall it proves to be an excellent fighting game for the anime enthusiast.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

A very fun anime fighter that is easy to pick up for newcomers into the fighting game genre and is also fun for more veteran fighting game players.
It is visually pleasing and the gameplay will leave you feeling BADASS!
I recommend!

Dragon Ball FighterZ is not just a game; it's an emotional rollercoaster that took me back to my childhood, reigniting my love for Dragon Ball and filling my heart with joy and nostalgia. As a lifelong fan of the franchise, I can confidently say that this game captures the essence of Dragon Ball like no other. From the moment I booted up the game, I was greeted with stunning visuals that perfectly mirror the anime's iconic art style. The attention to detail is simply breathtaking, making it feel like I was controlling my favorite characters in an actual episode. The vibrant colors, the fluid animations, and the explosive special moves all contribute to an immersive experience that left me awe-struck. But it's not just the visuals that make Dragon Ball FighterZ an emotional journey. The gameplay itself is a testament to the love and passion put into this game. Each character feels unique and faithful to their source material, with their signature moves and personalities shining through. The combat is fast-paced, intense, and exhilarating, allowing for strategic battles that keep you on the edge of your seat. The satisfaction of landing a devastating combo or unleashing a spectacular super move is unmatched. Beyond the gameplay mechanics, the story mode of Dragon Ball FighterZ touched me on a deeply emotional level. The game's original storyline takes players on an epic adventure that explores themes of friendship, sacrifice, and the enduring spirit of Dragon Ball. The dramatic cutscenes, the heartfelt dialogues, and the nostalgic encounters with beloved characters brought tears to my eyes more than once. It reminded me of why I fell in love with Dragon Ball in the first place and rekindled that fire within me. Dragon Ball FighterZ also shines in its online multiplayer component. Competing against other players from around the world not only offers an opportunity to test your skills but also fosters a sense of camaraderie within the Dragon Ball community. The online community is passionate and welcoming, and the competitive matches are intense and gratifying. It's a testament to the game's ability to bring people together through their shared love for this incredible franchise. As I sit here, reflecting on my journey through Dragon Ball FighterZ, I can't help but feel overwhelmed with emotion. This game has taken me on a ride that I will cherish for years to come. It rekindled my love for Dragon Ball, brought back precious memories, and reminded me of the powerful impact this franchise has had on my life. Dragon Ball FighterZ is not just a game; it's a love letter to the fans, a celebration of everything that makes Dragon Ball special. If you're a fan of the franchise or even just a lover of fighting games, I implore you to experience this masterpiece. Get ready to unleash your inner Super Saiyan, because Dragon Ball FighterZ will leave you emotionally charged and eternally grateful for the memories it creates. Kamehameha!

This is an incredibly fun 2D versus fighter that has unfortunately been handicapped by the (still) lack of implemented rollback netcode, and the previous year or two of DLC characters uniformly dominating the game, especially a busted Lab Coat 21, which has lent itself to emanate pay-to-win vibes. There was a meager balance update not long ago, supposedly another one in the future, but I was genuinely hoping to come back to this game upon desperately-needed rollback being implemented in the game since it was officially announced at EVO 2022. Yes, almost a year ago, and still no rollback - although Bandai Namco still insists it will happen.

These flaws aside, I wholeheartedly enjoy and recommend this game if you're a fan of Dragon Ball or fighting games in general. If you're new and intimidated by fighting games, I assure you that this game generally follows the formula of "easy to pick up, hard to master", and straight-up mashing will still be a fun experience before you take the time to formally learn the mechanics. The game is still going relatively strong, it's still a main stage EVO game this year in 2023, the player base is there even without console crossplay, and it's guaranteed that its popularity will rocket to the stratosphere upon rollback netcode becomes implemented and available.

This is a great entry point for fighting games that are team based. Like most Arc fighting games, DBFZ has a great training mode to give you somewhat of a basis and after that it's up to you on exploring on growth in the fighting game itself. It's a extremely flashy game thanks to that of being within the dragon ball franchise which for DBZ fans is also a good gateway into fighting games for this group as well if you want a fighting game that you can play with friends and sometimes play competitive modes get this game. It's a great entry point similar of that of Guilty Gear Strive, it's just a bit more chaotic and have a bigger franchise behind it.

My only issues with this game are:
1. If you want to play MnK instead of controller it allows you to, but there is no option to actually switch input so that it would give you MnK keyboard button context rather than controller buttons.
2. This isn't really a gripe geared towards this game specifically it is more just towards fighting games in general, but there is a Dpad roll in the game that initiates special moves that definitely goes off of a pretty slim actuation point. It is VERY hard to get consistently and can be pretty frustrating. I personally would like to see fighting games do away with actuation based moves and instead just make more combo buttons and more ways to defend or avoid against those attacks. There's probably a way to bind macros for such moves making it unfair in online play and hardware based moves shouldn't be a part of any online game for above reasoning.

Other than that the animations, characters, and music is pretty good!

Although this is a fighting game, the only thing this game excels at is the fighting. It's very fun.

Unfortunately, the game fails at everything else. The story sucks narratively and gameplay wise. It's just repeated fights. While it does allow you to practice sort of, its just a slog. The alternative modes, just more fighting. No pretext, no purpose, no unlockables, just DLC. 

Speaking of which, the game feels very incomplete without the DLC. A major portion of your roster is locked behind it, and it is very unsatisfying to see. Also the netcode issues can make online play inaccessible, which is a huge downside. All these factors build up and bring down a great game. Even though Dragon Ball Xenoverse 2 factually fights worse, the variety of things to do in the game has caused me to play it 5 times more than this. It sucks that Dragon Ball Z: Budokai Tenkaichi 3 remains one of the few dragon ball fighters that has balanced these two factors. Fighting games need more than great fighting to be a great game.

I really enjoyed my first 10 hours of play time. Then I found out all the DLC doesn't expand the story mode. That was a huge let down. I'm kinda mad I only got this at 50% off. I should have waited for a bigger discount.

-Serious lack of special abilities(Frieza makes me sad asf tbh. No death beam)
-No CAF(not a huge issue but the main boss looks like my Majin from Xenoverse 2 :D)

-No way to escape combos

+Dramatic events(There are far too few IMO but its still a +)

6/10, get it on sale like i did. But more t han 50%. This game isn't worth 60$ by a long shot.


30 hour Edit:
The only consistancy in the game i've found is that the AI on Hard Arcade doesn't have an air combo or normal combo damage regression. Kid Buu just comboed me from 90% full health to 0 in one Ultimate Move combo which at the end was 130 hits. The AI Shouldn't have a drastic damage advantage over the player. The only reason this game has high reviews is due to the game being flashy. I love all things DBZ but I'd rather play Famicom DBZ games. Broken AI =/= Challenge.

It goes against Everything DBZ that you can't break a combo, especially ones so high. After reading and then performing how to Infinite people in corners with specific characters, I can't help but lack the understanding of why the developer hasn't patched these out or introduced the ability to break combos, at the very least with support characters. This is the first time i've ever regretting purchasing a DBZ title. I just want the Non-Online achievements because ive already been a part of cancerous game communities online. Just pick the 3 spammable characters and spam your medium attack until you're done. Boring as hell.



Edit: 100h After waiting several years, I came back to see if they fixed anything. Nope. In fact they made it worse with paid DLC being extremely OP online. Which has attributed to the death of the game. Several thousand people playing online scattered all over the planet mean extremely long(30-60m) queue times. Most of my game time is now waiting on a ranked match just to get the achievements. Using a VPN helps but it makes match making worse than it already is sometimes. Save yourself a headache and don't bother with it unless youre like a lot of us and just straight up DBZ fans and non-canon story doesn't bother you.

Between the accessible auto combos, homing attacks, and simplified command inputs, Dragon Ball FighterZ is an inviting gateway into the world of fighting games for newcomers-whether you're a Dragon Ball fan or not. Those easy controls can open doors to some spammy behavior, but just as often it's satisfying in a way that does right by the Dragon Ball name. Dragon Ball FighterZ has enough depth and complexity to glow as brilliantly as a Super Saiyan.

Shout out to hitconpelo. Gave me the most fun match I've had in a long while.

As for the actual game itself, pretty fun. Dragon Ball FighterZ strikes a sweet spot between being beginner friendly and having a solid skill ceiling. The auto-combo system is good for getting a general feel of the game, and the inputs are simple enough for anyone to pull off. A three-character team system also means more room for error and improvisation, especially with the Limit Break buffs and Sparking.

The matchmaking also works surprisingly well, so you won't get paired against a player too far out your league (unless you don't mind that).

Also runs decently well on low-spec PCs, always a good thing. So if you're a casual player or just a DBZ fan, this is a game worth checking out.

Just please get it on discount, with the edition that gives you the first DLC pack at the least. I wouldn't recommend getting this game at full price, but it is worth playing.

Pros:
- Nice graphics. Low/mid-end PC can run the game.
- Main Z-fighters and villains are available.
- Movelists are easy to learn. (I'm able to play although I'm not really good at fighting game)
- Super attacks and meteor attacks from each character are magnificent like you are watching anime.
- Each dialog when characters face each others or be the same team is related to anime. If you are DB fans, you will understand.

Cons:
- Looks like AI has read inputs and has been a bit quicker than players' characters. AI quite takes advantage on players. There are ways to beat AI but getting S or A to rise up the upper path is hard.
- Boring story. No replay value.
- Overpriced. (recommend to wait until it's on sale)
- What is fatal error? It might appear without any reasons.

Neutral:
- I play offline mode. Arcade mode (random) is my favorite. Don't care of online mode.
- Some combos in training mode might be impossible to do by casual gamer but not necessary to do them all.
- You can use a keyboard but using a gamepad will get better experience.

[b][u]PROS[/u]:[/b] This is one of the most fine tuned Dragon Ball fighting games on the market.  The controls feel tight & well tuned, the action is fast & frenetic, & everything about it shows the quality the team put into the game, down to individual animations being tied to different aspects of Dragon Ball as a whole.  The visuals pop & represent the style of the series very well, & the audio just keeps that nature going, down to the ability to select songs from the Dragon Ball anime.  The wealth of additional fighters through the season passes will also please many fans.  Finally, with rollback netcode on the way, the online is only bound to get better.  That isn't to say it's poor where it is now, just having a few kinks.

[b][u]CONS[/u]:[/b] The story mode is a bit of a sticking point.  Where it is an entirely new story rather than treading old ground, it becomes a rather uninteresting slog with next to no variety on the way through it.  On top of that, the three campaigns don't line up with each other, making the first two feel like filler.  The online does have bouts of lag here & there, but that should be fixed with rollback netcode.  Cheaters & rage quitters aren't as prominent as they were years ago, but there's still no penalty for doing the latter of those two besides an eventual marking on one's name that takes far too long to take any kind of effect.

[b][u]ACHIEVEMENTS[/u]:[/b] This list can be a serious challenge.  Where many will be gotten through casual gameplay, some will not.  Arena matches are underutilized, & finding matches to play, let alone spectate, might take a bit.  Set For Life is an insane grind based achievement that will eventually be gotten through logins thanks to the sheer amount of Zeni giveaways tossed at the player.  My Power Level Is 530,000 is by far the most difficult, requiring players to win ranked battles all the way to 530,000 BP, an insane requirement considering one loses BP on lost matches.

[b][u]FINAL[/u]:[/b] Dragon Ball FighterZ is in contention for being the greatest Dragon Ball game on the market, & one of the best fighting games period.  The charm & aesthetic the game has just oozes from every beat of it.  With exception to the lackluster story, the game provides a great deal to those fans of fighting games, fans of Dragon Ball, & those who are interested in one or the other.  Without a doubt, this is an easy recommendation.

I was never big into tag fighters, and it had been years since I consumed any DBZ related content before I picked this game up, but this is my all time favourite fighting game and it single handedly brought me back to check out DBS (which has varying degrees of quality, but I'd rather not get into that.)

As expected, Arcsys knocked it out of the park with the visuals. Honestly I think how good this game looks made it easier for me to learn. When I started, I didn't mind getting wombo bombo'd because it just looked so damn good getting 2 touched by some vet. Supers are flashy, impactful and just plain fucking awesome.

If there's one thing I think DBFZ has in spades, is its labbing potential. Johnnys can spend hours in training mode just labbing out different combos with different combinations of characters. To this day, I still see plenty of lab monsters posting insane combos that leave me speechless. It's precisely because I am so spoiled with this in DBFZ that I couldn't play GG Strive as my main FG, there simply isn't much to lab there.

Mechanically, it feels really good controlling a character. A good portion of the cast share a very similar BnB, so picking up a new character shouldn't take too long. This doesn't mean all the characters feel the same though, as you dive deeper into each one, they all feel very different from each other (yes, even the 75 different gokus). Motion inputs aren't too strict and are limited to 236/214 or 22X. The game also features 2 autocombos (Light and Medium) for new players to jump in with. I also appreciate how Light autocombo isn't just a newbie crutch, and does have practical uses as you get better and learn new combos.

Of course, no game is without its flaws, and DBFZ has some that might turn you away. Long combos are a big part of the experience, and if you don't like watching 15-30 second combos, you probably won't enjoy this game. I'm also iffy about how at some point after season 3, they decided to buff everyone and many characters have near-fullscreen range projectiles / gap-closers, which can make neutral feel alot more scrambly and unga bunga.

The community is still alive and well, and DBFZ has already been confirmed for this year's EVO. With rollback on the horizon and a recent balance patch, now is a great time to dragon some balls

Title: An Exquisite Blend of Style and Character Appeal!

Review: Dragon Ball FighterZ is a visually stunning and captivating fighting game that showcases the artistic brilliance of the Dragon Ball universe. While the gameplay mechanics and strategic depth are commendable, it's impossible to ignore the visual allure of Android 21. With her striking design, elegant demeanor, and confident presence, she adds an undeniable charm to the game's roster. The attention to detail in her character model and animations is impressive, capturing her beauty and grace. Android 21's presence evokes a desire to witness her story unfold and experience the depth of her character. Dragon Ball FighterZ offers a fusion of style and character appeal that immerses players in a world where even holding Android 21's hand feels like an enchanting experience.

Title: Dragon Ball FighterZ: A Dynamic and Spectacular Fighting Experience

Rating: ★★★★☆

Dragon Ball FighterZ, developed by Arc System Works, brings the iconic Dragon Ball series to life in a visually stunning and action-packed 2D fighting game. With its vibrant graphics, faithful character representations, and fast-paced gameplay, FighterZ successfully captures the essence of the beloved anime, providing fans and fighting game enthusiasts with an exhilarating experience.

One of the standout aspects of FighterZ is its remarkable visuals. The game beautifully replicates the vibrant art style of the Dragon Ball series, with characters that look as if they jumped straight out of the anime. The animations are fluid, and the special moves and energy attacks are visually spectacular, adding a sense of awe and excitement to every battle.

The gameplay in FighterZ is both accessible for newcomers and deep enough for competitive players. It adopts a simplified control scheme, allowing players to unleash devastating combos and flashy super moves with relative ease. However, mastering the mechanics and learning the intricacies of the game's tag system and assist attacks adds depth and complexity for those seeking a competitive edge.

The roster of playable characters is diverse and expansive, featuring a wide range of fan-favorite fighters from the Dragon Ball universe. Each character is faithfully recreated, not only in their appearance but also in their move sets and special abilities. From Goku and Vegeta to Frieza and Cell, every character feels unique and offers a different playstyle, providing plenty of options for players to find their preferred team composition.

The Game is great and it has a lot of content with the DLC adding so much to the overall experience, which many players and critics have praised. However, some players and critics have cited the game's repetitive gameplay mechanics and lack of variety in character moves and combos as major drawbacks, which can make the game feel stale and predictable over time. Additionally, the online matchmaking system has been criticized for its inconsistencies and long wait times, which can make it difficult to find matches quickly or easily.

Another criticism of the game is its reliance on auto-combos, which can make the game feel less strategic and rewarding for experienced players. Some players have also reported issues with the game's netcode, leading to lag and other online connectivity problems, which can make online matches frustrating and difficult to play. Additionally, playing in casual mode can be challenging, as it often pits players against opponents who are either smurfing (playing under a new account to face lower-skilled players) or who are far above their skill level, resulting in difficult matches where players are often trapped in infinite combos and unable to fight back, which you may as well grab a drink and popcorn to watch the show.

The netcode of the game is so shootily made that if someone is lagging it'll make the game feel like it slowed down to .25x speed and when you go back to normal it'll feel like the game is too fast. The characters and teams that are in the meta are going to be meta forever since the game isn't going to get anymore updates with the last update adding Lab Coat Android 21. Ranked seems more like a fun experience since most times even in the high ranks there are people who have just gotten the game since most of the sweats are playing casual preying on the inexperienced players who don't know how to play.

I highly recommend this game if you like the publisher's fighting games & are a fan of the Dragon Ball franchise. As for achievements I wouldn't recommend trying to 100% do to certain modes you can't get enough players for these days to get certain achievements. Never would have thought a game would make me a simp for another Android in the series, makes yea want 21 to achieve her goal in full (Pun intended if you know the characters methods haha)

Countless hours of fun with bros.  

Some dislike this game because of auto combos, or only quarter circle command inputs or they feel it needs more mechanics.  That's fine if that's you.  In my view though, this game can be a lot of fun with people, and it attracts a very large audience, and it can get your friends into 2D fighting games when they might not have found out what a wonderful thing they can be otherwise.

I really do like the combo system it has, as well as the assist system.  I feel the game is really fleshed out now and has enough depth to keep people engaged at any level.  

Mechanics like Reflect have a ton of uses, counter play, create interesting interactions, and can take place of a lot of other options you might miss from other 2D fighters.

The gameplay is overall, more reactable, and about half of the confirms will come from neutral rather than pressure or setplay.  But that isn't a bad thing to be honest.

The characters do play pretty similar in a lot of aspects, but it makes hopping between characters not as much of a challenge, but there's still enough uniqueness to each character to make them compelling or fun in my view.

This might not be the deep dive tons of options super fast paced gameplay of Xrd I love, but it is very fun.

I'm looking forward to the rollback patch so it finally feels smooth online!

Hopefully with the incoming patch they will also even out the playing field a bit more, top level play is a lot of A21 and fusions and not a lot else.  While they aren't miles above other characters it'd just be nice to have it evened out some more.

An actually fun and entertaining dragon ball fighting game if you are looking for something outside an arena fighter. 
3v3 takes a bit while to understand but once you get it team building is a fun process. 

The game has new player friendly combos with same button presses repeatedly if you land them that even look decent and a one button super dash that zooms you over to attack your opponent and that's a simple way to feel like you are doing a lot but it wont take long before you see something and go "wait... you can do that?" Then training mode does a decent job of teaching many of the rules and systems properly so you can "get good". Seriously the skill gap is so noticeable in 1v1 games if you like the game at all your ego will probably check you into trying to learn more and its a capable training mode (if you don't just blame the online connection.... its not great) and the options in training are great. Watching another player use one character demolish all three of yours can be humbling in a more unique way than other online games at least as far as what I am personally used to BUT! I will say.. once you land some cool combos you kinda feel a little super if you know what i'm sayin. 
I can't recommend story mode unless you love the dragonball universe because its all fan service character interactions layered behind a generic boring plot and weird battle path you follow to reach the end of levels? That's not why you get this though its the high pace frenetic combat that will have you watching long block strings, combos and cinematic supers but again if you love DBZ you are probably down for that.

Also if you don't want to play online or story there is an arcade mode for playing against cpu but its pretty bare bones and local play to enjoy turning your family and friends who don't play to space dust if that's more your thing. 

I hear rollback netcode is coming and that is apparently much better and once that comes you might even be able to take ranked mode seriously but even without it (ranked due to good online) it is tolerable to play others for fun.

So fighting games are quite unique in terms of what a player wants.
So how does this game do?

1. Style: This game's style is off the charts. The developers did an amazing job staying true to the design of the anime and manga, and overall the game is pure eye candy.

2. Character choice: While this game does exclude a few cult favorites of dragonball, it has such a huge cast of very playable characters that it more than accomplishes a wide selection of good characters

3. Gameplay: This will definitely be a break point for some players, and that's fine. Defense is hilariously strong in this game. Extremely varied wakeup options combined with defensive moves, assists, invincible supers, and many more character specific responses allow the defender to have lots of agency, quite often to the detriment of the attacker. If this is a dealbreaker, allow it to be. This game is not for everyone.

Overall, a great adaptation of an extremely beloved IP. It's only gotten better over time, and still has an active community. Enjoy!

While not necessarily being a *bad* fighting game, after having played Guilty Gear and Blazblue before this, FighterZ feels like a big step down. Every character feels almost exactly the same to play (with a few minor exceptions) and the superdash feels like a brainless movement tool to skip past having to deal with neutral. Maybe there's more deep stuff hidden behind tons of practice, but as a mostly casual player there just doesn't seem to be much to this on a surface level compared to other fighting games. Visuals are still very impressive though. Probably worth picking up if you're a huge fan of DBZ, or are super new to fighting games and wanna give them a try, but definitely wait for a sale before you buy.

As an avid Dragon Ball fan, this game is awesome to me. It fills me with that nostalgia hit I always get from participating in this franchise, from when I watched it as a kid. I did want to preface this review with this in case I am using rose-colored glasses

However, this game isn't just that for me. It's also a quick to learn fighting game that has a skill gap. Anyone can play, but it is hard to master. I absolutely love the graphics of this game. Every fight seems to pop off the screen. Everything is so exquisitely detailed in that classic Toriyama style with a twist.

There are some drawbacks though. Not all the fighters can be played, a lot have to be purchased through DLC, and sometimes the special moves can be a bit complicated to pull off. You really need a controller to play this game, but that is the norm with these kind of fighting games anyways.

Overall, if you're a Dragon Ball fan looking to make this purchase, and are into these fighting games, I highly recommend it! I thoroughly enjoyed it! 7/10

There are definitely some areas of this game that I think could be improved upon in a sequel, and definitely some things I would like to see in the next patch *cough* rollback *cough*

But overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who is looking to get into fighting games, and those who are veterans of the genre. This game truly embodies what makes Dragon Ball special to so many of us, and you can tell that every inch of this game is dripping with character. The roster of this game is impressive to say the least, and each character really feels like their own work of art as far as presentation goes. 

Pulling off combos in this game feels like you are jumping your opponent and unleashing an ungodly amount of hurt on them. Getting hit by combos in this game feel devastating, and like you are in a playback montage on your opponent's YouTube channel. The frustration, and glory are both equally addicting. And there is nothing more satisfying than landing a combo you've been trying to get down for hours.

This game rewards your success with an amazing amount of flare and flashiness, and it's enough to get anyone hooked. 

Diving deeper into the game though, there are some present issues that really do need to be addressed. For example, the net code and online play in this game is some of the most inconsistent I have ever seen. The developers have been saying for years that they plan on implementing rollback netcode into the game, however it hasn't come. Currently they are claiming that it's coming with the next season, but we will have to see. That improvement alone would make this game leagues better than it currently is. Also the DLC characters in the game, have clearly received more love and care than the rest of the base cast. They have made changes here and there to address the power creep, but nothing big enough to say it's not an issue. Some characters really could use new tools to bring them up to snuff with the rest of the cast, or at the very least some aspects that make them stand out a bit more.

Overall though, this game is just really fun. 8/10

"I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started Dinkum and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories."

It's a fun game, I never really play online because of the lag, but, I have noticed a few things that bother me...
1. The AI spams the same thing over and over again, to the point where it becomes annoying and somewhat predictable
2. Zamasu AI at level 100 is somehow able to break through your guard? I've seen this several times, where I'm blocking high, and he does the flying slash thing and he just hits me through the block
3. Tien AI, this AI is an actual PAIN! I hate Tien AI at level 100, the moment he hits you with a level 3, and he gets back down, HE TRIES TO GO FOR THE VOLLEYBALL FIST EVERY SINGLE TIME! I managed to predict this, and now, I can prevent him from hitting me with that.
3. Grappler AI at level 100, this is actually annoying, for no reason do they use the command grabs, even when I'm in the air, they go for it!
4. Counter AI at level 100, so, Vegito AI doesn't use his counter AT ALL, but Jiren uses it to the point where it just becomes spam... I throw out an attack, hup, Counter! Throw out a ki blast? Counter! literally do nothing? Counter(whiffed)!
5. CAPTAIN GINYU OF THE GINYU FORCE! Ok, this 1 is self-explanatory... level 50 to 100 Ginyu AI just spams the same attacks over and over again, to the point where you literally can't do anything! You're constantly in block stun, meaning you can't even reflect anything, this is bothering me because it's just so annoying!
6. AI sparking, the AI using sparking itself isn't the problem, it's just, they use it too early! They don't use it conservatively, like, they're low hp, or they're going for high damage, no, level 75-100 AI is blocking, you're attacking, SPARK! Nothing you can do about it, and then, they proceed to NEVER BLOCK AGAIN WHILE SPARKING IS ACTIVE! This is annoying, because either the AI doesn't spark at all during the entire game, OR, they spark IMMEDIATELY when you're hitting them in block stun!

If you're considering purchasing Dragon Ball FighterZ on Steam, I would advise against it. While the graphics and animations are stunning, the gameplay itself quickly became dull and uninteresting. The moves and combos are limited, and the battles feel repetitive and unsatisfying.

Another issue is the online matchmaking, which can result in long wait times and frequent disconnects. Even when I did manage to connect to a match, the lag made it difficult to enjoy the battles. Overall, the online experience left much to be desired and detracted from the overall enjoyment of the game.

In conclusion, while Dragon Ball FighterZ may appeal to die-hard fans of the franchise, the lackluster gameplay and problematic online experience make it difficult to recommend to others. There are many other fighting games out there that offer a more enjoyable experience, and I would suggest looking elsewhere if you're in the market for a new fighting game.

literally the same experience as any fighting game. you play it a little, it's fun. you play some with friends, it's fun. you make a curious decision to start playing ranked. [b] this is where the fun stops. [/b]

as with basically every fighting game ever, the low-to-mid section of the ladder is LITTERED with smurfs. the moment I see a player card that reads "36 games played, 30 wins", is the moment I know that the next three minutes of my life are going to be absolute garbage. the fact that this shit isn't moderated in any way whatsoever is nothing short of idiotic, and the ranked experience here as a new player is nothing short of rancid ass.

Let me tell this and explain why i would not  recommend this to anyone. The game is liquid booty. Let's start with the most pressing thing.  Matchmaking, you  get a white,blue, green, orange, red and pinkish Card to signify that you have won a certain amount and what not. That is the most Useless thing in the existence of the game.  You are paired up with people who had thousands of Hours logged into the game. Making this game VERY anti beginner friendly game. It better to go into ranked to get a Fair fight. F***ing Tekken 7,Guilty Gear, MK,street fighter is more friendly than this sad excuse of a fighting game. 

Let's talk about Gameplay... You have 4 buttons, Light, meds,heavy and projectile, you can block and what not, the basic for any fighting game. The problem comes when the meta has and will always be rushdown oppression. If you are new; I am sorry put down the controller for 30 sec while someone gets a 120 hit combo on you,all because you can't block one repetitive string that stun locks you out of recovering.  It is more apparent with the insane power creep. You have Gogeta(SS4) who can hit you with his 3 bar even when it should miss like goku's kaio ken move,You have kefla who can hit you anywhere on the map, You have Android 17(Ranger) who can outblitz you cause he can just zip zip zip everywhere and then you have the most egregious offender MUI Goku who ,not only online but AI as well, can blitz you because A) most of his move are counter moves B) He Can just dodge everything. oh and did I tell you that he can even counter your beam supers? You see the issue? 

Put him with any of the other people who are power crept to hell and congrats, you have a brain dead team who can just sweep and stun lock the shit out of you. The base roaster have it's offenders. (looking at you hit.)

You know the worst thing about this and why I would not recommend this to people. The Community, The community is the most toxic thing i have Ever seen. If you talk about VERY apparent issues, They tell you "get good" and " you are just a casual" Yea, no duh, you have to sink a minimum of 1000 hrs in the game, have a minimum a 1000 wins to be even heard. They do not help new players, all while they sit there and play like they a have a world tourney to uphold, They beat the shit out of you then complain when people Rage quit, They sweat so hard you can smell it coming through the netcode. Then complain that you are not fighting because you literally can't! Then when you point this out, they default back on what every Elitist say Get good or I don't like Rage quitters in my game!

POSTED: MARCH 11, 2022
This game is really fun and very challenging. Very open world and have a lot of content which you need to figure out yourself, with mechanics that I enjoy a lot.

First of all, it works fine in console, but it stutters a lot on pc and have terrible optimization, even with controls.
But the game is still new tho, so it may change in the future.

The start of the game is pretty good so far, but there is a lot of minor flaws like the scarcity of armor and ways to level without farming for hours straight.

The PVP is fun, although metas and high damaging magic ruins it sometimes, it's really fun!

The Co-op on the other hand is not that viable, it works and are bareable, but could've been better.
It is coop, but there's too many restrictions and too many steps to get 1 session, which you need to repeat when you die to get back in the session.

The weapons are really good, and the way you acquire them is pretty fun, but it is disappointing that magic deals too much damage and also the fact that one of the highest damage dealing weapons is easily acquired at the start of the gaming without beating the boss.

Overall, this game is fun if you like souls-like games or simply hard single player campaign games, I do hope that they fix a lot of things tho.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently downloaded DragonBall FighterZ and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Dragon Ball FighterZ is an amazing fighting game, one that stands toe-to-toe with the best. I have always considered the Street Fighter (for 2D) and Tekken (for 3D) to be the best franchises in this genre; but I can say that DBFZ has taken the crown for me. Being based on an anime series I like certainly helped, but previous games for the same IP didn't have the appeal this game has.

Gameplay is important in any game, but for fighting games it's even more so, because it's a genre that depends on tight controls, the correct pacing and movements to be good, and DBFZ offers all that, with a very good transcription of what is seeing of television and what happens in the battles. Presentation is excellent, with a story mode that is fun to play; battles are frantic, but understandable, with quick movements and powerful attacks. All in all, it's a great game, one that can offer a lot of hours of fun.

My only complaint is that DLCs are expensive for what they offer. New characters are interesting, and the base game already offers a good roster, but optional content could be cheaper. Anyway, I recommend this game, as this is my favorite since the appearance of the 1990's franchises that are still relevant today.

I live in the American Gardens building on West 81st Street, on the 11th floor.
My name is Patrick Bateman.
I'm 27 years old.

I believe in taking care of myself, in a balanced diet, in a rigorous exercise routine.
In the morning, if my face is a little puffy, I'll put on an icepack while doing my stomach crunches.
I can do a thousand now.
After I remove the icepack, I use a deep-pore cleanser lotion.
In the shower, I use a water-activated gel cleanser.
Then a honey-almond bodyscrub.
And on the face, an exfoliating gel-scrub.
Then I apply an herb mint facial masque,
which I leave on for ten minutes while I prepare the rest of my routine.
I always use an aftershave lotion with little or no alcohol,
because alcohol dries your face out and makes you look older.
Then moisturizer, then an anti-aging eye balm, followed by a final moisturizing protective lotion.

There is an idea of a Patrick Bateman.
Some kind of abstraction, but there is no real me.
Only an entity-- something illusory.
And though I can hide my cold gaze...
and you can shake my hand and feel flesh gripping yours...
and maybe you can even sense our life styles are probably comparable,
I simply am not there.

I can only imagine Arc System Works sitting in a room and saying, "What if we did Marvel vs. Capcom with Dragon Ball characters, but made it so fast you'd have to be a crack-addicted squirrel to keep up?"

This game is an absolute blast to play casually.  You can pick it up and immediately pull off amazing looking combos and shoot Ki blasts while flying through the air.  For me, this is the closest a game has come to feeling like you're actually playing an episode of DBZ or Super.  Movements are fluid, combos are crisp, animations are perfect, and hits are impactful.  The story mode is lackluster, but passable enough as an excuse to learn the basics.

Once you get past using Autocombos and start learning the actual fighting system underneath, there is no end to the depths of the combos you can pull off.  It feels like an even faster BlazBlue, with combo strings of 20+ inputs.  You will find yourself pulling off a normal combo, launching your opponent into the air, comboing them into a wall bounce, grabbing in the air into a sliding knockdown, and calling an assist to keep the opponent juggled while you reset and start the combo again.  Input buffering makes it fairly simple to pull these combos off, though it becomes trickier online if you have a large frame delay.

Note that I said simple, not easy.  This is a game you can play casually and never touch the depths of the systems, or a game you can lose hundreds of hours in if you choose to master its mechanics fully.  It's rare to find a game that handles both well, but DBFZ manages to do so.

At this point, there is not a huge community, but I really don't have trouble finding online matches when I want them.  It's old enough now though that I would definitely wait for a sale -- it's 90% off during most sales.  If you have any interest in DB or Fighting games, as you probably do if you're reading this, it's absolutely worth picking up for $6.

A lot of fighting games find themselves torn between fun and technicality. Developers usually have to tip-toe across a metaphorical tightrope to make sure they don't fall entirely into one or the other. Balance in competition is key, thus many devs obsessively try to tweak their game into being perfectly competitive. This often results in rigid, super-streamlined fighters that almost feel like an elaborate game of charades. You think a legitimate bout is occurring, but really, it's all by the numbers. 

Dragon Ball FighterZ says: "Y'know what, screw it, just swan dive into the fun tank." 

100+ hit combos on a whim, planet-destroying instakill moves everywhere, tons of combinations and transformations, you name it. Casual players have an accessible and flashy combat sandbox to play in, while pros can dig into the meat and make some really badass stuff happen. Believe me, I played online for hours one night, and no two players played the same. It really reminded me why I got into fighting games to begin with.

tl;dr: Arc System Works found the power to go beyond, and by God, I hope they keep it up.

I am a 44 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing uno and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. My son hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son so many happy memories.

An edit to the following review felt necessary after playing the current meta of the game for a good while. Most of what I've detailed below still stands, but there are some things worth adding.

First things first, the top four or five characters of this game are far, [b] far [/b] better at playing it than the rest of the cast. You don't have to play them to win, to be good, or to have fun, but playing against them without having them on your team, you can feel the difference in capability almost immediately. Team synergy is far more important in this game than the raw power of individual characters, but man. Vegito, Lab Coat 21, Gogeta 4, Gohan, and Gogeta blue are playing a different game. 

Does this change whether I believe the game is worth picking up and playing? Absolutely not. It's still fun, easy to pick up for new players, there's a ton of room for personal choice and creative freedom, the game is reasonably balanced despite the top tiers, and the playerbase isn't inactive. There's a ton of players playing this game at every skill level, so you [b] will [/b] find good matches, and you [b] will [/b] have a ton of fun discovering new stuff and getting better. Rollback is still (hopefully) coming, and that will only open up matchmaking even further. This game isn't going anywhere.

Original review:

TLDR is at the bottom for those of you that don't want to hear me preach.
Dragon Ball Fighterz is the perfect fighting game for newcomers to the genre. To see if DBFZ is right for you, consider the following questions:

[b] -Do you like fighting games, or want to break into the genre? [/b]
[b] -Do you like Dragon Ball? [/b]
[b] -Do you like mashing buttons and watching cool shit happen? [/b]

If you answered yes to any of these questions, congratulations, you should buy DBFZ.
DBFZ is a 3v3 tag-team fighter, and although the game is fairly well-balanced, there are certainly characters within it that are much better off than others. However, the bottom of the tier list is not very far from the top. Any character can work on any team! Pick whoever you want, jump into casuals, and play some matches. The game goes on sale fairly often, and while you don't need the DLC to play, most of the DLC characters are better than the characters in the base game. So if you like it, shell out the extra cash. Wait for it to go on sale before you do buy it though, please.

The game has a great modding community as well, with skins, stages, music packs, aesthetic overhauls, whole new characters, and even a mod that replaces the voice lines in the game with lines from Dragon Ball Z Abridged. Bobs your uncle. You can only play online against other people using mods though, so... don't take them online. Anti-cheat won't let you play if you do. 

Boot Camp takes you through EVERYTHING the game has to offer, and I mean e v e r y t h i n g. Training mode has a LOT of options, letting you practice almost any interaction you can think of: learning how to tech throws, setups for your character, practicing your own mixups and combos... all with the ability to change the frame delay, input delay, enemy counterattack settings, etc. Its a lot. RathFGC has a pretty good guide to training mode on youtube, it's a little old, but nothing available within the mode has changed since then; new characters have been added and balance changes have been made, but the mode remains the same. 

The servers are pretty packed whenever I log on, no matter what time of day it is. Casual matches are always easy to find in my experience, but ranked is a totally different story. You wait forever for matches, and when you do find one, they're not even close to your skill level most of the time. At least you can fuck around in training mode while you wait, right? 
Also, ranked matches are first to two, while casuals can be rematched any number of times. I personally wish ranked was first to three, but that's just my opinion.

Online play right now is... questionable. When you and your opponent both have a good connection, the game plays so smoothly that I can't even tell it's online sometimes. But, if it slightly dips, or god forbid, one of you is playing on wifi, get ready to lag your whole ass off. The developers are working on implementing rollback right now, which would ideally solve these problems, but right now, it isn't great. Not unplayable at a casual level, but not great.

Aside from online play, the game doesn't have all that much to offer. The story is not well-written, although it will give you a few laughs if you're a fan of the series. It takes a good long while to beat, and you have to beat it to unlock Android 21, so. Good luck. You can also buy her in the shop in the game, or for $4.99 on steam if you don't want to wait. Arcade mode is much the same; not very deep, fun maybe a few times, but you have to play it to unlock SSB Goku and Vegeta. You can also get them both by hitting certain Zeni milestones in game, which takes a little bit longer if you aren't playing that often. The AI is brain-dead, and once you get even slightly okayish at the game, it will never present a challenge again. The combo trials aren't helpful and don't teach you anything particularly useful about any of the characters, although they are pretty fun to blaze through. Some of them haven't aged well with patches though, and are oddly tricky to complete.

One last thing. In my experience, this game has a bit of a smurfing problem. Just a warning.

TL;DR: I love this game.

Pros:
-easy to pick up with a decent amount of depth and set play once you get invested
-a good size community of players, never hard to find matches in casuals
-every character is viable and has dedicated players that have found good tech already, and new stuff is still being found, surprisingly
-teaches a lot of fighting game fundamentals in a beginner-friendly way by making most options reactable
-the devs are in the process of implementing rollback netcode
Cons:
-half of the roster is DLC, and that half is better than the base cast
-have to play the garbage arcade/story modes to unlock SSB Goku, SSB Vegeta, and Android 21, unless you want to pay
-the current delay-based netcode is dodgy and not great to play on unless both players have great internet connections
-ranked matches are hard to find and even harder to get paired against someone close to your skill level
-a non-zero amount of smurfs

The last fighting game I played before this one was Tekken Tag Tournament for the PS2 so I been out of this genre for a long time.  I am, however, I fairly big fan of the dragon ball franchise.

Graphics are beautiful.  Every character looks amazing.  And even the backgrounds are very nice.  The art in this game is better than a lot of the art from the actual show.  The game uses a mini town hub to select what activity you want to participate in and everything looks competent there.  But all the gushing is really for the story mode cut scenes and the actual battles.  I really can't praise the graphics enough.

Music is pretty good.  It sounds "dragon ballish" if that makes any sense.  It's nothing you will find yourself wanting to jam outside of the game.  But it all seems to fit.

The sound is a mixed bag.  Mostly good.  One of the best things I want to point out is it seems to have the entire Japanese and English voice casts from the show.  I've watched the entire series in Japanese and English dubs.  If it ain't the cast from the show in each language then they need a freaking award for best imitations I've ever heard.  And you can switch between these freely in the sounds menu.  During combat it can get pretty noisy though.  It all sounds good - hits, combos and special attacks.  Characters have special voice lines when they do certain things.  But in certain situations it can all overlap a be a bit of overload.

Practice mode.  As someone who was away from the genre for a long time this mode was pretty important to me in the beginning.  I want to say overall it does a pretty good job at teaching you the basics of the game.  It does challenge you with some pretty dang difficult combo strings to pull off that seem unrealistic in actual matches with a live opponent.  But maybe I am just noob here and I will get to that later.

The game claims I am roughly half way through the story mode.  And I have to say it is fairly lengthy.  I don't know if that is par for the course nowadays for the genre.  But there are A LOT of cinematic scenes and dialogue.  An overall critique of the story itself is... eh.  It's there.  I won't spoil anything.  You can tell they put some effort in.  But even half way through I am still a bit confused about wtf is going on but maybe it will all make sense in the end.  There is also an item system that seems exclusive to this mode but for me it just makes the experience even more confusing.  I think they could have done without it.  Not a single encounter has been challenging.  I didn't see a difficulty option and maybe it has been ramping up at a snails pace.  They must have thought they had a top notch dragon ball esk story lined up that even if it's your first time playing a fighting game you could experience it.  The difficulty is flatter than a plate full of piss and the item system adds needless complexity.  But other than that it's fine.

Local multiplayer is near perfect.  Almost everything you would expect is there but nothing that detracts from it's identity.  I'd like to have seen some handicap options as my only local opponent is my 9 year old daughter.  It's like if it were Goku vs. Krillin in dbs.  I can't really go all out on her.  It would be cool to give her the win if she could land a single combo string on me or something rather than me having the drop the quality of my already poor quality play to give her the W or make it close.

Online play.  Shew... There is a ranked and casual match making system.  You can edit the options before hand to try and find only folks that have a good connection to you.  Seems to work well because I've not had any lag during any of my matches.  So at least for me, online felt about as good as local.  But now I am going to talk a bit more about how exactly games seem to play out.  Every single character can execute nice looking combo strings by repeatedly pressing a single button.  Some characters will even mix in lows and overheads.  Veterans who have spent a lot of time with the game will know what is coming and when.  Noobies like myself who has not memorized every characters combo strings are at a disadvantage.  But needless to say knowing how to block and counter with some sort of punish is important.  And I mentioned earlier that I may be noob when it comes to thinking some of the elaborate combo's aren't viable in actual matches.  But hot damn. Most of the folks I have played against were exceptionally deadly if they landed even one attack.  I've been combo'd for nearly half a characters health multiple times by very grand and impressive looking combo's.  I have managed to squeak out the occasional win against these behemoths with shear fundamentals.  It really felt like I had to outplay my opponent constantly because one slip up from me was devastating.  I'm going to say it's great because I did enjoy the challenge and I felt next to no lag.  But if you are not willing to invest the time you will get smoked.  I never once played against a person similar to my skill level or lower.  To be expected as old as the game is - everyone active online seems to have the ability to be somewhat competitive.  Side note: Not a dead game as of this review.  Always tons of folks in the lobby ready to que up.  Never had to wait long for a match.

Lastly... DLC content.  I'm not new to the concept.  But this def pops my cherry for how monetization works in modern fighting games.  I bought the game on sale with a fighting pass that came with a few of the oldest DLC characters.  I still lack 12 characters.  Even if they go on sale at half price for 2.50$USD I'm still looking at 30$ to complete the collection.  On top of the (I think it was 15$ paid for the deal at the time) for the base game and a few extras.  Which is a bit steep imo for how old the game is.  But not terrible since you can acquire everything for roughly 50$USD if it's on sale.  And you are encouraged to buy the DLC character's.  They all seem better than the original in the base game via various means.  More overheads and lows in there combo's to force your opponent to be more proactive with blocking.  Downright quicker, maybe more range on a few attacks.  It's all there.  You can win with base game characters,  But your work is cut out for you.  I complain about cost because the age of the game.  But if you are really having a good time it's not that bad of value - again, with a sale.  Also kind of sucks how some characters are simply outclassed and become jokes.  I guess that is also just like the show too though.

Oh and there is also an in game currency you earn perpetually that is used to unlock color schemes for characters and various things for your lobby avatar.  Unlocks work in a loot box type manner and you can earn duplicates but those seem to turn into a special currency.  But when you use that special currency, to my understanding, you cannot get duplicates.  A round about way to have you play more.  Also if you are playing in an online lobby around certain holidays there are certain things that can only be unlocked during those holidays.  So that is kind of neat.

Overall to super summarize I do recommend.  Even to newer folks to the genre.  Especially to fans of dragonball.  If you are a fan of both what have you been doing with your life to not have this?  All the characters have iconic attacks from the franchise.  It feels good, looks good and sounds good.  Expect no quarter this far in to the games life cycle when it comes to online play.  Everyone is dangerous and absolute monsters.  Prepare for a challenge.  However, I would only recommend buying on sale.  The full price for the base game and all DLC combined is absurd.  But an easier pill to swallow when at least 50% off.

The base game is alright. But the problem is they only give you like half a roster and expect you to pay an additional €5,- per character. Which is a complete sham when you consider that you take 3 characters with purposefully limited movesets and specific roles in your team to essentially build one full character. Even different forms/transformations of the same characters are used as an excuse to just sell you a whole "new" character. Having or not having certain characters greatly impacts your options. Oh and the base game is [i]still[/i] full price after all this time as well. Costing €60,- for what is essentially a bare bones starter edition that after all this time should definitely be half price at the very least. One that in hindsight wasn't worth the price even at launch, monetizing all aditional content like it's a F2P title..

Sure the roster was very limited but I figured hey you know what the basics are all here (a few characters to play with, a story mode, some arcade modes, etc.) they will probably update and support this game for a while to come. What I didn't know was that every little snippet of content was going to come with another price tag attached. There is a way to do DLC's and this ain't it. Loved playing this at launch but quickly stopped when I noticed what they were doing with their cash grab DLC's. Gone are the days of old when a company making a DBZ fighting game would take the time to create a fleshed out roster of characters with complete movesets and sold us a finished game.

Total cost of the game is now at €160,- and still rising... Only buy on sale at like 75% discount if you ever get that lucky.

DLC ruined the game neutral and the fun. That's why professional players like Wawa and Go1 are retired from competing seriously. Never have I ever played an inconsistent fighting game in terms of balancing like this one. 

Season 1: Oki meta which forces a guess of high or low. Snap vanish meta which is tagging your opponent character for another resulting three-way guessing of rock paper scissors (High, Low, or Air Grab). Cell one-touch + sparking-less damage that does 50% no assist needed. Kid Buu's damage is abysmal, especially landing level 3 on top of it.16 level 3 Oki meta, 21 level 3 Oki meta, Bardock level 3 Oki meta, a true 50/50. 

(I dropped the game after messing around with Bardock and Broly. Too many variables as in opening opponents in raw defense with command throws and level 3 Oki meta.)

Season 2: Came back after the DLC character GT Goku was added. The meta in general was tuned down the last time I visited season 1. Snap vanish and the level 3 Oki meta was reduced still strong.  My team was GT Goku, Vegito, and Cooler. During those matches, I didn't know GT Goku was a meta character so I think most of his tools were mediocre until the tournament event when Japan players along with Go1 used a "Spirit Bomb" level 3 which turns into a combo or a true 50/50 on Oki. So the Oki meta was tuned down and given to a single character that does 90% by GT Goku self. Next thing everyone has GT Goku on their team while repeating the meta-strategy same as Season 1.

(Just realized the piccolo meta. That was nerfed and buffed along the way and finally BALANCE including Zamasu. Piccolo is not really considered a meta character though debatable. The meta was Hell zone grenade which is when a bar is dispersed for a ki blast ambushed which is considered a 50/50. That is fair due to spending resources during the session.)


Season 3 (Current): At the beginning, every character that was non-meta was giving buffs. Goku, Trunks, Krillin, Frieza, Cell, etc, including the meta characters although were given, nerfs still strong. The game was overwhelmingly balanced and had a good momentum after announcing Ui Goku and Kefla. First Kefla was released and then UI Goku. Once again another DLC character, UI Goku to no surprise became a meta character with command throws. Now failed to mention that in Season 2 ninety percent of the DLC characters have command throws. In this Season command throws are buffed by cutting bar disbursement by 50%. So, back to UI Goku's command throw. The move itself can be transitioned into three stances with a mid that's +3 on block, a double DP, and a cancel. The damage from command throws is insane. There are over 49% of the cast including DLC have command throws. The final characters of Season 3 are Master Roshi, Super Baby, and Super Sayian 4 Gogeta. THEY ALL HAVE COMMAND THROWS. 

Season 3.5(Current): So the meta has shifted to characters with command throws that due damage right. Season 3 was wrapped up until another character was announced. The laziest character for the final season is Lab Coat 21. It could have been Whis or Hercule, whatever. Lab Coat 21 is by far the most broken fighting game character that I have ever seen in the FGC. Lab Coat 21 has an overhead mix-up, level 3 Oki, over 5 LOW OPTIONS, Command grab, an INVINCIBLE COMMAND GRAB THAT REDUCES YOUR CHARACTERS DAMAGE BY 21%, and a grounded stomp that picks characters off of Oki. THE ONLY CHARACTER THAT HAS THAT IN THE GAME BY THE WAY.

Command throws are crazy wait unit fusion meta. Fusion meta was never a thing until season 3.5 when Vegito can reach across the screen with a medium punch, safe on block too. On counter hit does 65% because developers felt Vegitos damage wasn't already good enough. Vegito Medium Punch has push back if failed to mention this before so good luck punishing it. The same can be said with Gogeta Blue just damage buffs.

Conclusion: I do not want to get political but this is what happens when a woman is in full control of a fighting game. No honor whatever makes the most money can keep the players hooked. I am done with this game. I do not like losing to lag. I do not like having buttons eaten by delayed frames. I do not like getting command thrown in lag or in general. I do not like broken characters that take away damage during the session. I am STRETCHED from playing Dragon Ball Fighter Z. As a Dragon Ball Z, Kai, Superfan that has played every Dragon Ball fighting game, Budokai, Tenkaichi, and Ranging Blast this has to be the s****** fighting game that I have ever played. I will most likely purchase the next one when it comes out until then PEACE OUT.

As far as Fighting games go, FighterZ is a great fighting game and an even better Dragon Ball game.
Moderately simple campaign (as most Dragon Ball game stories go) and is fun and to the point.

[b]Hi, I'm DragonBall FighterZ's official subreddit creator, and I'm posting this review, with the help of our current megathread created by Electric over /r/DragonBallFighterZ![/b]

Dragon Ball FighterZ is a Dragon Ball fighting game developed by Arc System Works and published by Bandai Namco. It released in 2018, and has had three competitive seasons since then. Each competitive season has also had an accompanying DLC release schedule, with over 17 DLC fighters released since the start of Season 1, and two more coming before the end of Season 3.

A Season 4 is highly likely, and Arc System Works (along with BamCo) have been supporting the competitive scene very heavily through sales to extend the game's lifespan and prize pools for tournament play.

[b]HOW TO PLAY[/b]

FighterZ can be purchased on any platform or PC, and will run on most systems. The game frequently goes on sale for as low as $9, and you can find current system requirements via Steam. Several DLC passes are also available, and can be purchased on sale during the same sale windows. The game can generally be found at a discounted price at least once per month.

If you don't wish to buy DLC, the base game comes with 21 characters.

[b]DO I NEED A FIGHTSTICK OR ARCADE STICK TO PLAY?[/b]

NO, you do not need any special tools or equipment to play or be good at the game. 75% of the competitive playerbase uses a standard Dualshock controller. Any professional player will tell you that FighterZ has been designed with "ease of access" in mind. While it isn't the easiest game to learn, it's very beginner friendly, and there are no entry barriers other than how much you're willing to learn.

That said, if you're dead set on obtaining some cool peripherals, highly consider checking out Battlebeaver Customs for controller orders and HoriUSA or Hitbox for fight/arcade sticks. If you'd like to learn more about making a fightstick of your own, you can check out r/fightsticks.

[b]WHAT ARE THE DIFFERENCES FROM PLATFORM TO PLATFORM?[/b]

Playstation 4 is the most active, due to its use as the main tournament client. Other consoles are also well populated. PC players are also very active, though this may vary region to region. FighterZ is currently the most popular anime fighter on PC by far, and one of the five most popular fighting games on PC. It is considered one of the Big 3 competitive fighting games.

[b]IS THIS GAME HARD TO LEARN?[/b]

All fighting games are hard, but DBFZ was designed to be easy to learn for Dragon Ball fans that may not be experienced in fighting games, yet still hard to master. The game features easily performed inputs (quarter circles) and something called a "magic series," which is a combo that can be performed by 66% of the cast. The /r/DragonballFighterZ Discord server also features a litany of coaches and helpers who are more than happy to help you figure the game out.

The community itself is incredibly active and lively, and you'll generally find someone who can help you at all hours of the day.

[b]IS THIS GAME COMPETITIVE?[/b]

YES! As mentioned before, FighterZ is one of the "big three" fighting games right now. It's regularly featured at EVO, and with a possible fourth season on the horizon, the game's future is looking bright. Expect to find a ton of events throughout 2021, and likely beyond. A possible re-release with all of the DLC content may also come for next generation consoles, which currently feature crossplay with their predecessors.

You can also find the game's top players on twitch, but you can also observe fan favorites like DotoDoya, LotusAsakura, or learn from players like RathFGC, LordKnight, Rooflemonger!

[b]WHAT CHARACTERS ARE GOOD? DO I NEED THE SEASON PASS(ES)?[/b]

EVERYONE IS VIABLE, but there are some popular characters among the DLC cast. UI Goku (Season 3), GT Goku (Season 2), and Z-Broly (Season 1) are some of the standouts. You do not, however, need any of the DLC to play the game competitively. Among the base cast, Kid Buu and Android 21, for example, are highly regarded characters.

Though tier lists will vary from player to player, it is an indisputable opinion that every character is viable.

The Season Passes will deliver any character from the season in its name.

[b]Overall, an amazing fighting game. For more, come say hi over /r/dragonballfighterz, we'll be more than happy to have you there with us :)[/b]
