This is one of the best fighting games I have ever played. It was easy for me to pick up despite my lack of experience with ArcSys fighting games, the animation, artstyle, sound design and voice acting are all top notch, and while the story is its weakest link, it was still decently entertaining in each arc.

I have ape brain and only wanted to master the basics, so I got pretty far in the ranks, but I only get matchmade with people that attend tournaments. I just want to shoot a laser, but I need to be reminded of how little I care about getting better compared to my opponent, so I don't want to play anymore. That and the fact that you can't escape the people that play on wifi.

It's easier to pick up than most other fighting games, but the fgc will make that not matter, so honestly you're probably going to end up hating it before long. But like many other games, it's good with friends. That being said, most people that would play this are try hards, so if you and your friends aren't and you also want to play a fighting game, then let me tell you how rare of a sight you are. I don't think you exist. But if you do... sure. It looks nice, basics will do you fine, but don't be too good or you'll never win again.

TL;DR Are you sure you want to play a fighting game? Yeah they're fun, but... really? ... Okay, go ahead, but you will mald before long.

It's not the "Marvel vs Capcom" we wanted, but it's the one we deserved.

In it's final state, FighterZ is the best 2D fighting game of this decade. The years of support, updates, DLC, and regular online events have made it fairly balanced and approachable, while also maintaining a fan-focused presentation and high skill ceiling. Action and Special inputs are reasonable and forgiving, so the process of discovering and crafting combos is incredibly satisfying. To be perfectly honest, inputs in FighterZ are simply unmatched. Some of the DLC characters can be tricky to learn, but if you tell the game to do it, you will not be told "no." Other fighting games will restrict the timing of inputs to certain frames and such if you want to pull-off a sick combo, but FighterZ is purely visual. Make a light-attack, press the heavy-attack before the animation ends. When you lose in FighterZ you will rarely, if ever, blame the game for misreading your intentions. I love it, A+ 10/10.

Offline modes are fine. Nothing extraordinary. You have 9 simple arcade modes, a straight-forward story mode with RPG mechanics, combo challenges, and tons of guided training modes. The story mode can be slog, but it's also fully voice-acted by the original cast and stuffed to the brim with fan-service dialogue. In the dojo, you also have the "tournament of power" modes, which are essentially a supplement to the lackluster arcade (with beefy in-game currency rewards). 

At it's core, FighterZ is a well-written love-letter to the series, which just happens to come in the form of a lightning-fast, hella-hype tag fighter. If you aren't a Dragon Ball fan, however, the complete game offers enough character variety and unique presentation to keep you interested long-term.

I keep coming back to this game, despite taking a while to get used to, and not typically being a Marvel-style fighting game player, this is consistently one of my favourite fighting games, both as a FG player and a Dragon Ball fan. Very accessible, but still with lots to learn.

The only thing I wish there was more of is co-op content; I'd love for the party battle raids to be permanently accessible and even customisable, they're so fun, and they're a nice breath of fresh air; it's rare to get good PvE co-op content in a fighting game, but it's a niche I've always personally appreciated.

The game is just ok. I am a fairly big Dragon Ball fan, but this just ain't doin' it man. I guess it is my fault since this is a competitive game and I'm a casual, so instantly my opinion doesn't matter.
The story is actually good, but not the story mode. I like that Yamcha is useful again as well as the other side characters that Z and Super throw to the side. But the actual gameplay of story mode is... eehhhh.
It's serviceable enough I suppose, but enemies start off really weak, then go to way too strong. I get why the final boss is like that, but why everything else? 

Arcade mode, is an arcade mode. That is basically it.

This game is just ok. I would recommend it only to highly competitive fighting game players. However, my biggest problem with this game, is not the game or story itself, it is the pricing.
$80 FOR A FIGHTING GAME!? I got this on sale for like 6 bucks yet I still kinda feel ripped off. This is a complaint I have for all of modern gaming, but this is preposturous. AT LEAST SONIC FORCES, MY LEAST FAVOURITE GAME OF ALL TIME, HAD STUFF TO DO. This is just an excuse to throw tournaments and nothing else. 

Instead of spending $80 on this, spend $70 on Xenoverse 2, an actual good game with thought, care, and stuff to do put into it.

5/10
